The dragon emits red lead toward the crucible’s query.
The immortal registry records the name as the elixir ripens,
The netherworld’s ledger removes the entry as life is restored.
On what clouds do the feet alight as they return?
Straight into the Three Purities to thank the sacred countenance.

To match true yin with correct yang,
Three years of work complete, frost congeals.
The divine tortoise enters and exits the geng-xin position,
The cinnabar phoenix soars in the jia-yi direction.
The nine tripods first radiate twin auspicious qi,
Within the three primals, the five hairs’ light is renewed.
If in the dust there are those of like mechanism,
Together we shall dwell in the misty heavens of the deathless land.

The path of cultivating life is difficult within,
The deluded merely pore over ten thousand scrolls.
Water and fire balanced—this is the medicine,
Yin and yang askew—no elixir forms.
Abide in the feminine without losing the masculine to dwell,
In darkness, without deficiency, the white naturally dries.
Recognizing this true and wondrous secret,
Why fear wind and rain hastening decay?

Having swallowed but a single grain, one is at peace,
The twelve-storied tower and nine-bend stream are linked.
The geng tiger circulates, feeding on sharp snow,
The jia dragon writhes, spouting numinous springs.
Lü’s second corresponds to three thousand days,
Within the nine nines, ninety thousand years extend.
Only when there is affinity may it be transmitted,
Never lightly divulged to others.

Who knows of the divine water in the Jade Flower Pool,
Within which lies the foundation of life and destiny?
Its operation depends on dragon and tiger,
Its drawing and adding rely entirely on Kan and Li.
Morning and evening, the yellow gold powder is exhausted,
In an instant, the jade-like marrow is refined.
After a thousand days of abstinence and ingestion,
One casually ascends the cloud ladder.

The clouds of the Nine Heavens are still, the crane flies lightly,
Holding the bamboo slip, it flits away from the Great Purity.
The red dust beyond the body changes at will,
The white stone within the furnace forms in an instant.
The nine-plumed phoenix dances in the void,
Five-colored clouds arise beneath the feet.
Turning the head, one returns to the heavens above,
Wishing to bring sweet rain to parched mortals.

The infant descends the jade steps in leisurely fashion,
Holding the mystic pearl, it comes straight down.
At midnight, purple clouds drape its plain form,
Several times, crimson qi veils the peach’s bloom.
In its faint smile, the mechanism turns,
As it lightly moves, doors and windows open.
This is the true child of my family,
How could the foolish and ignorant casually guess?

As soon as the heavenly tally descends from the Jade Capital,
Three thousand days accumulate effort.
Praying to Heaven and Earth, the golden crucible opens,
Gathering yin and yang, the jade pot is sealed.
Suddenly, the mortal frame is capable of transformation,
Deeply knowing the wondrous Dao is no empty scheme.
When the time comes, ask the elders in the dust,
Does this mystery exist in the world?

Who recognizes the accomplished ones in the world,
Those who in their lives understand the method of silver in water?
A single staff props up Heaven and Earth,
A three-foot Kunwu sword slays gods and demons.
Deeply drunk, they sleep in the moonlit grotto,
Loftily chanting, they scorn the red dust.
Since awakening within, for the rest of their lives,
They have won the eternal spring of Penglai.

The red furnace advances the ridicule to refine golden essence,
A single numinous pearl pierces the chamber with light.
Shaking Heaven and Earth reveals the power of the Dao,
Escaping life and death demonstrates the work’s progress.
Carefree, they leave traces across the Four Seas,
Returning to the Three Purities to establish their names.
Straight up the five-cloud path, the journey is steady,
Purple simurghs and vermilion phoenixes come to welcome them.

If people of this age wish to learn longevity,
First, the pivot must move day and night.
Within the indistinct, focus the will and qi,
Within the void, solidify the original essence.
Dragon befriends tiger, three cycles complete,
Hare runs, crow flies, nine returns are achieved.

Having refined a crucible of sacred elixir,
The path home through the five-colored clouds grows clear.
No gain nor loss, no words to speak—
In motion, they perform their work; in stillness, they rest.
They drive the crimson ox to plow the cosmos,
Scatter jade grains to sow the mountains and rivers.
Cultivating without fear of a thousand days’ labor,
They know that partaking grants ten thousand years of life.
Today I show you, for you are trustworthy—
I teach you to become an immortal in this world.
No need for pairs or trios,
Only at Kunlun’s first crag.
When moisture comes, the passions naturally submit;
When heat arrives, the nature fears it cannot be tamed.
At times they enter the Three Primordials’ gate,
When idle, they return to the Nine Bends’ river.
In this world, some can endure the firing—
Their lifespan matches Heaven and Earth, peerless in all.
From beginning to end, all lies within the Jade Capital,
Though once they walked the earth as ordinary men.
First, they swallowed essence and consumed qi from the realm of being,
Then, awakening to principle, they returned to truth and entered non-being.
Water and fire naturally achieve the *ji ji*,
Yin and yang harmonize and correspond of themselves.
From the furnace, the elixir of extended years is refined,
While the seas and tides may shift from flourishing to withering.
Free from fame and profit, they roam at ease,
Meeting wine and song, they join in the revelry.
For years, they have not passed through the sacred gates,
A thousand years they dwell only in the immortal realm.
Thrice they advance with water and fire,
Truly, husband and wife are gathered in one place.
Once the elixir is complete and the work accomplished, the body takes flight,
Leaving the dusty chamber to rise above the mortal stream.
Vast and boundless, ask not where it ends—
Carving insects and seal script are but the blossoms of the Dao.
Only by guarding the center and forsaking learning does one grasp the profound;
Embracing the One in silence, one first perceives the sublime.
There is a thing like the yellow chrysanthemum’s pistil,
Yet no color like the green peach blossom.
Do not wear out the mind’s earth with vain effort,
For smelting iron and refining gold only leads further astray.
When the returning elixir’s work is complete but they have not yet ascended to Heaven,
They first guide others among men to find their own verdant path.
A staff at both ends bears the sun and moon,
A single gourd conceals the mountains and rivers.
Poems flow freely in moments of leisure,
Wine is drunk in abundance, leaving coins behind in drunkenness.
If you ask what wondrous method I cultivate,
It is none other than the mercury and lead within the body.
Half red, half black—the mystery of the Dao,
Water nurtures true gold, fire nurtures lead.
They reconnect the three inches of qi from past years,
And circulate it through one cycle of Heaven.
The refining depends entirely on the power of yin and yang,
Advancing and retreating must rely on the authority of sun and moon.
Once this work is complete beyond the Three Isles,
They steadily ride simurghs and phoenixes to meet the immortals.
Returning to the origin and restoring the primordial has reached Qian,
Able to ascend and descend, they are called the Flying Immortals.
The arising of the first yang is the day to begin the work,
Nine revolutions complete the year of attaining the Dao.
To refine the elixir, seek the water within gold,
To establish the furnace, first set up Heaven within Earth.
Here lies the principle of the returning elixir—
Without encountering an extraordinary person, vow not to transmit it.
The nine-and-five flying dragon has ascended to Heaven,
In due course, the power of the Red Emperor will follow.
Delighted to meet the mercury pearl congealing at high noon,
Fortunate to encounter the lead mother forming the profound mystery.
The wild ape submits of itself—what need for refinement?
The untamed horse is tamed without the whip.
Once the single pill of Heaven’s elixir is refined,
The mind’s earth becomes forever firm and unyielding.
Who in this world understands my family?
My family dwells in a glory apart.
Their overflowing chests store the Registers of Ascension,
Their rooms are filled with cinnabar refined by fire.
They drink the immortal wine of Heaven in great draughts,
And constantly cultivate the undying flowers of the grotto.
If the mortal stream asks of my livelihood,
Everywhere, multicolored clouds scatter in profusion.
Saliva quenches thirst, qi serves as sustenance,
Their home lies in the Three Purities’ realm of the Jade Emperor.
When refined in the golden crucible, the outer turns white,
When cooked in the Jade Void, the inner becomes thoroughly yellow.
Only then do they know the Azure Emperor dwells in the Li Palace,
Only then do they trust that the golden essence is stored in the Water Mansion.
The common crowd seeks the wondrous principle,
Yet the *Cantong Qi* holds but a few lines.
A purple edict descends with the simurgh from the Jade Capital,
The Primordial Lord summons them to the Three Purities.
They then partake of the cinnabar from the golden crucible,
Brushing their cloud-embroidered robes as they ride the crane’s carriage.
Two celestial youths bear the jade pendants to guide them,
Fair maidens of the moon hold the sashes to welcome them.
Only after their work is complete and they have met the Perfected,
Do they truly believe the immortal capital holds their names.
Cultivating, cultivating, until they reach Qian,
They are then called the Drunken Immortals among men.
In the world, time hurries the brief scenes of life,
Yet in the grotto, flowers and trees enjoy endless years.
Their form soars on sheer cliffs, no ordinary bones,
Their spirit dwells in the Mysterious Palace, a Heaven apart.
I only wish the master would glance this way again,
To inquire beyond the profound into the even more profound.
Sitting alone with an empty mind, they turn the Yellow Court,
Not following the times into profit and fame.
To preserve age, they hold only the true unified qi,
To cultivate life, they leave behind the hundred spirits.
Morning by morning, they refine the fluid and return it to the Jade Mansion,
Night by night, they face the origin to nurture the Jade Flower.
Do not sigh that the old man finds joy in poverty,
For with ten years of work complete, they ascend to the Three Purities.

**Parting from the Guest**
Men receive qi and are endowed with yin and yang,
Their bodies equal Heaven and Earth, their lifespans long.
Those who honor their origins can live forever,
Those who slight their primal ancestors fall into oblivion.
The Three Palaces have their own method of reversing the flow,
All things possess their own means of operation.
The jade of Kunlun’s mountain, close at hand,
How many know it is the king of medicines?

**Parting from the Guest**
Few tread the path to the azure clouds,
Speak not of rise and fall—such matters never succeed.
Why is there no name on the golden tablet?
In the Jade Capital, there must be an immortal’s name.
Clouds return to the vast sea, dragons a thousand feet long,
The moon fills the long sky, a crane’s cry rings out.
Deep gratitude to the enlightened sage-emperor of the Song,
Who understood the vermilion edict and summoned the master.

**Presented to Chen Chushang**
The net of Heaven is vast, its mesh wide,
Yet one body comes alone to the Hua Mountains’ region.
After the cold clouds depart, the waning moon remains,
When spring snow arrives, it inquires of the Great Void.
The Six Grottoes’ Perfected return to the Purple Mansion,
A thousand years of simurghs and cranes grow old in Cangwu.
Since the master’s passing,
In all directions, few remain who are true men.

**Lament for Master Chen**
Who among the Daoists of Luofu shares his stream?
Clad in grass, eating bark, they scorn kings and lords.
In the world, the sexagenary cycle matters not to them,
Within their gourd, Heaven and Earth are free.
Counting the moves of a half-finished game as the river moon dawns,
A long whistle echoes through the autumn mountains and seas.
After drinking, they turn their heads to speak of the return,
Pointing afar to the white clouds at the edge of the sky.

**Presented to the Daoist of Luofu**
A wanderer three thousand *li* from home,
A cloud-and-water body for seven hundred years.

When merit is complete, Penglai becomes a guest pavilion;
When the Dao is perfected, tiles and rubble turn to gold.
In the sleeves for welcoming guests, wine is ever stored;
Within the alchemy furnace, another spring abides.

Virtue amassed and masters sought—what lack to fear?
Since ancient times, Heaven and Earth show no partiality.
This monk now appears.

Heaven births one thing, transforming into the Three Powers;
Yin and yang interact, congealing the sacred embryo.
Dragon and tiger proceed in order, banishing yin ghosts;
Tortoise and serpent reverse their course, and the fire dragon arrives.
The Infant daily consumes the Yellow Dame’s marrow;
The Crone feasts on the White Jade Cup.
When merit is complete, one naturally dwells beyond things;
In the human realm, cold and heat follow their cycles.

*Record of Ancestor Lü, Scroll Four ends*

**Record of Ancestor Lü, Scroll Five**
**Literary Records**
**Sixty-One Seven-Character Regulated Verses**

Stars and constellations gather, departing the *Li* homeland;
The waxing and waning of sun and moon aid the Medicine King.
For three periods, fire refines the golden tripod’s treasure;
With five talismans, water cooks the jade pot’s broth.
Heaven and Earth invert, the dragon gathers mist;
At *Mao* and *You*, the tiger devours and radiates light.
Entering the chamber, seize the mechanism—
A single cinnabar pellet transmutes the body into pure yang.

Blood drips from the hairline, eyes like rings;
Breath exhaled forms clouds, enraged at the world.
How to endure the myriad injustices?
A single formula must sweep away the fierce and stubborn.
Where the flood dragon is slain, the deep sea churns;
When the raging tiger is vanquished, distant mountains are uprooted.
For burying worldly passions and bearing righteousness,
The sword’s gleam is stained with bloody marks.

Snow falls thickly as dusk descends;
Golden goblets urge the strumming of the scorched paulownia.
Poems recited at the feast, moments unmeasured;
The sword dances before the banquet, swift as the wind.
Why raise cups at midnight?
Suddenly, eyes blaze with fury, and he soars into the void.
Who among them lacks loyalty or filial piety?
A head is seized and brought to the seat.

**Two Poems Presented to the Sword Guest**

A single golden pellet of elixir ensures longevity;
True lead must be refined with *jia* and *geng*.
Fire draws the red phoenix’s marrow from the south;
Water seeks the black turtle’s essence from the northern sea.
The tripod follows the four seasons, uniting at the center;
The medicine is dispatched through the three origins and eight trigrams.
With fasting and discipline, the nine transformations are achieved—
Surely, upon entering the mouth, even ghosts and spirits are startled.

Deep in the emerald pool, a true man resides,
His countenance like peach blossoms, his form like silver.
Though his hair and beard remain unblemished, he possesses the art;
His rosy complexion never ages, for he communes with the divine.
To Penglai he must go—now is the time to depart;
The yellow robe on the rack transforms into clouds.
Though mulberry fields may turn to vast seas,
A single pill of common medicine secures a thousand springs.

The furnace nurtures cinnabar, temples unmarred by gray;
Borrowing fame and profit, he dwells among men.
Having met a man of resolve who transmits the divine medicine,
He delights in kindred spirits, his smile ever bright.
The *Dao De Jing* of Laozi is entrusted to him;
The Purple Tenuity Star permits their shared ascent.
Fortunate to be gathered by a superior man,
In this world, he yields to none in leisure.

**Presented to a Person**

Who understands that long life is my planting?
Refining true *qi* within the Three Terraces.
Knowing full well the ascent to heaven in broad daylight,
Yet following the red dust back to the world.
When the black tiger moves, rain and dew pour forth;
Where the red dragon plows, jasper and coral grow.
Swallowing but one pellet of golden elixir,
He soars into the azure skies, never to return.

Amid piled clouds stands the starry capital;
Only the bold recognize the hidden treasure.
Green wine lulls him to sleep through idle days and months;
White duckweed stills the wind as he fishes rivers and lakes.
Ever aligning his bearing with the Dao of Heaven,
He does not waste words on worldly fools.
The mountain paths are distant, untrodden by men—
Has anyone lately heard news of Lord Mao?

Cranes serve as chariots, wine as provisions,
For he yearns for the land of immortality, where none die.
If earth’s veins can be shortened,
Why not extend human years?
Stars and constellations often appear within the gourd;
Sun and moon are ever concealed in his sleeves.
Should you wish for the common folk to meet him,
He never strays from the path of mercury.

Magic mushrooms have no seed nor root,
Yet those who drink and consume them revive their souls.
As long as mist and rosy clouds sustain the years,
Let the crow and hare race through Heaven and Earth.
The Infant clings only to the mother within yang;
The Crone must face the honored one atop her head.
Once attained, it remains for a thousand ages—
No tombs or graves are left for descendants.

Who in this world comprehends these words?
Cease clinging to fame and profit in your heart.
Casually downing cups of wine to the full,
When inspired, chanting a hundred verses.
Beyond the world, rosy clouds serve as companions;
Within the gourd, sun and moon are ever fair.
When the time comes and merit is complete, where will he return?
Straightaway driving a cloud chariot into the grotto-heavens.

Disciples of the Mysterious Gate sit at the center;
Obtaining the tally, the wise and good move the Jade Emperor.
Beneath the pillow, mountains and rivers harmonize with rain and dew;
Within the flute, sun and moon merge with Xiao and Xiang.
The *Kan* man meets the retiring *Jin* woman;
The *Li* woman ascends to wed the *Mu* youth.
Truly, husband and wife together uphold their resolve,
Establishing teachings that entangle yin and yang.

Pointing afar to the high peak, he laughs aloud—
Red rosy clouds and purple mists arise before him.
Often in the dusty market, none recognize him;
Ever in the mountains, cranes welcome him.
At times, he plays with the jade toad to drive away ghosts and demons;
At night, he boils the golden tripod to cook jasper blossoms.
When the time comes to journey to Penglai’s grotto,
Know that my immortal family bears a name.

**Mocking the Worldly**

How laughable are those who ask of my home—
A staff bearing clouds and things, trailing mist and rosy clouds.
His brows conceal lightning—no idle boast;
His hands plant golden lotuses—no vain pride.
A scorched paulownia, three feet long, sustains his livelihood;
A gourd of fine wine is his way of life.
Riding a dragon, he roams far to the three isles;
Through long nights, none share his moonlit repast.

By the winding river’s bend, he sits and lies in contemplation;
A single long path leads to the heavens’ edge.
Auspicious clouds gather to attend the cinnabar palace;
Auspicious vapors linger, rising as white smoke.
Lead and mercury now become the supreme medicine;
*Kan* and *Li* today conjoin the divine elixir.
Its power can preserve life, ensuring endless youth—
It lies within the human heart, not in difficulty.

The Mysterious Gate’s principles are ever more profound;
The root of immortality resides in mercury and lead.
Knowing this as the true guardian,
Harmonizing the Six and One also aligns with Heaven.
On Jade Capital Mountain, lambs frolic;
In the Golden Water River, stone tigers slumber.
The essential wonder can birth the awakened original body—
With diligent heart, all becomes naturally so.

Though high officials may be noble, he does not respond;
Those who speak of immortality are free to wander.

To seek the stone-liver, one meets the clam-sea;
In search of sweet snow, one crosses Yingzhou.
Mountains and rivers, drunk, are released within the gourd;
Spirits and ghosts, at leisure, are gathered in the casket.

None before my eyes now recognize this truth—
Better to blend with the mundane over cups of wine.
Once I was invited to visit an immortal’s home,
Suddenly ascending Kunlun to feast beneath the moon’s radiance.
Jade maidens guide the azure mist’s embrace;
Mountain lads carry white spiders of frost.
From time to time, they pour thousand-year wine from the sea,
Often plucking flowers of all seasons from the gourd.

Now in the mortal realm, none know me—
Soon I shall wave my sleeves and vanish into mist and clouds.
The fire-seed in the cinnabar field breeds gold of itself;
Layer upon layer, pavilions grow ever clearer.
Two thousand deeds of merit manifest in a hundred days;
A journey of ten thousand miles to Penglai takes but a day.
Transcendence naturally leaves no ghostly record;
In the Jade Capital, immortals’ names endure forever.

Today I attend the Jasper Pool assembly,
Where nine-tiered banners and sacred maidens welcome from the grotto.
Studying Master Cui’s *Mirror of Entering the Medicine*,
The heart’s earth becomes ever more lucid.
The yang dragon originally emerges from the *Li* palace;
The yin tiger returns to be born in the *Kan* position.
When these two meet, they form the root of the Dao;
Traversing the five directions, one gains the name of the elixir.
If cultivators of the true Dao know this,
They shall surely ride the red dragon to the Jade Clarity.

Fleeting life is insubstantial, easily scorned—
Ingesting and concealing it, one harbors bones of marvel.
Not that one is unstained by the world’s dust,
But how else to transcend objects and commune with the formless?
Though conversation falters, emotions stir;
When walking alone, one moves lightly, effortlessly.
A single grain of the knife’s measure births five hues,
Flying cinnabar enters the grotto of immortals.

Do not delight in chanting celestial poetry,
For few in the world can recite such rare verses.
Accustomed to feasting on the Jade Emperor’s palace fare,
Once clad in Penglai’s grotto robes.
Hooves tread the sun’s wheel, red dew unfurls;
Phoenixes bear the moon’s horns, azure clouds take flight.
When shall I again rein the green-silk bridle,
And brandish the golden whip to enter the Purple Tenuity?

Yellow sprouts and white snow rain golden flakes;
Walking, I sing high; drunk, I chant low.
Sun and moon secretly uphold your chronicle;
Heaven and earth naturally befriend me.
Spirits vanish at the stroke of the Three Clarities’ sword;
Wind and rain soar as I play the zither.
Where shall I return after my southern journey?
Do not let the crane depart to seek me in heaven.

Cloud-coiffed and bright-eyed, bones grow lighter—
I say I sought the crane to reach Penglai and Yingzhou.
Discussing herbs all day, I know their flavors;
Asked of immortals, I gain their name.
At night, jade dragons pierce the azure grotto;
At dawn, cold tigers slumber in the silver city.
Again I plan to cast my rod in spring’s waters,
Recalling the Yellow Emperor’s voyage upon the sea.

Dragon essence and tortoise eyes harmonize;
The six-foot man can do naught against them.
In nine cups of water, the red child is refined;
In one furnace of fire, the yellow matron is nurtured.
When the moon is full, one senses escape from heaven’s net;
When merit is complete, one knows release from earth’s snare.
Half-drunk, I gladly swallow dragon and phoenix marrow—
I urge you, no longer invoke Amitābha.

Forcing oneself to dwell here severs all kith;
Too many wild scenes depart from the fitting verse.
If such poetry filled the mouths of ministers,
Even emperors’ hearts would stir at the name.
The Daoist robe and creeping-vine sash hang idly;
The hidden cap and leather crown remain unadorned.
Beyond this, there is nothing more—
A gourd of village wine, a zither.

Within Huayang Mountain lie many fields of mushrooms;
The old man of Huayang Mountain further extends his years.
By the green-pine crag, he climbs the lofty trunk;
Amid white-cloud drifts, he drinks the flying spring.
Neither cold nor hot, the spirit drifts freely;
From east to west, the qi flows endlessly.
When three thousand deeds of merit are complete, it is time to depart—
Do not speak of the grotto-heaven to the worldly.

The heart of heaven does not scatter, nor does the natural heart;
Success and failure have ever been thus, from ancient times to now.
Knowing the path, one should escape the world;
Lost in the way, one remains buried in obscurity.
The supreme medicine at one’s side awaits refinement;
Beyond objects, cinnabar is yet to be sought in detail.
The immortal’s realm lies within the grotto chamber, close at hand—
Do not let the waves of time drown your light.

I secluded myself in the Mysterious Capital, forgetting the seasons;
How many times has the azure sea turned to dust?
In the Jade Capital’s hall, I paid homage to the Primordial Beginning;
In the Golden Gate’s palace, I bowed to the Venerable Lord.
Bored, I ride the thousand-year crane;
At leisure, I recline upon the ninefold clouds.
Having learned the art of eternal life,
I dare not lightly transmit it to the world.

North Star and Southern Dipper observed within the palm;
The workings of creation secretly transmitted.
The golden hammer resides in the sleeve, dwelling in the primal abode;
The jade gate and stellar palace descend from the Supreme Mystery.
Though all the world seeks this Dao,
Who among them attains the mysterious pass?
The Dao is luminously present—heed its message.

At the rapids of sun and moon, one departs and returns.
The sun’s shadow merges with the primordial, naturally so;
Thunder and lightning rush into the central plain.
The red horse is driven long into the eastern palace;
The vermilion gates swing wide, floating upon the azure spring.

In wrath, I pluck the primal chaos to sing of sacred transformation;
In joy, I accompany the solitary moon to celebrate the new year.
Only then do I know this is the source of all life,
Attained by the benevolent before its transmission.
Six dragons together herald ascent to Qian,
As one suddenly perceives the subtle workings of creation’s power.
The true Dao is often chanted beneath the pale autumn moon;
Its ultimate words ever flow like jade-green waves.

By day, I ride a white crane to wander the Three Isles;
By night, I stand atop an ancient altar, crowned in gold.
A single year yields the elixir of a thousand ages—
Who among men would sully their sleeves with the dust of the world?

At the rapids of the Five Peaks, the scene is ever renewed;
Only the benevolent penetrate the formless, boundless self.
The celestial net turns, the Three Origins contend;
Earth’s veins pulse, and the ten thousand things are born.
Once awakened to the Valley Spirit’s communion with this Dao,
Who can govern their nature to cultivate the true?

Clearly expounded along the Central Yellow Path,
Amidst thunder’s roar, one attains the divine.
Longing to join the immortal singers and gain a lightened body,
I soar past Penglai to the highest heavens.
Crimson-crested cranes descend from beyond the clouds to greet me;
Purple-scaled fish rise from the sea to welcome me.
Chang’e’s moon osmanthus blooms in full;
The Queen Mother’s immortal peaches gradually ripen.
Gazing down, the sun’s chariot nears dawn—
Surely the mortal world has long attained longevity.

The four seas bustle, yet how few are at leisure?
Men’s mouths speak only of worldly dust.
Knowing you possess the Dao and have come to this mountain,
Why ask how one remains nameless in the world?
Twelve towers of jade conceal secret formulas;
Within five thousand words lies the hidden pass.
Only then does one know the tripod holds the elixir of immortals—
I beg but a single *daogui* to behold.

Sever the bonds of splendor, cast aside glory,
For from the first attainment, this is eternal life.
Once I shed my skin like a cicada by the brocade river;
Again, I changed my name upon Penglai.
Thrice dwelling, yet free from fortune or misfortune;
A single speck of dust, yet bound to worldly sentiments.
Unknowing of where merit’s fulfillment leads,
I shall ride this dragon straight to the Jade Capital.

In those days, my worth filled the imperial capital;
With a carefree wave of my arm, I returned west—a true man.
Alone, I possess ten thousand acres of white clouds;
Who lacks even a single branch of cinnabar osmanthus?
At leisure, I seek the fisherman’s guidance by the Wei’s bends;
Drunk, I ascend Lotus Peak, supported by a Daoist.
One day, I shall meet you again—
By bamboo streams and thatched huts, we’ll call to each other at night.

The golden hammer gleams as it dances upon the celestial steps;
Alone, I ride the dragon, departing and returning.
Beyond the heights, white clouds observe the sun’s cavern;
At ease, I slumber beneath the autumn moon, my arms outstretched to the sky.
The *li* flower, petal by petal, is born of heaven and earth;
The *kan* medicine, leaf by leaf, is nurtured by creation.
Drunk at dusk by the Nine Forks, I turn to gaze—
Beneath the Northern Star Mountain, bones gleam white.

I forge bonds ever deep with the Dao’s essence,
Daily following its ebb and flow.
Should you wish to commune with the crane beyond the clouds,
You must diligently refine the gold within the water.
When the elixir is complete, I fear heaven and earth too narrow;
Once ingested, what worry of illness or harm?
Though I have not yet departed for the Jasper Terrace, I still mingle in the world—
No harm in a cup of wine to delight in idle song.

Gathering my zither and sword, I descend through misty vines—
What fortune to pass this way today!
My appearance, though plain, remains tolerable;
Acupuncture, alas, has little effect.
I have read three thousand scrolls of immortal scriptures;
I have mastered the twelve ancient arts.
If you doubt these minor Daoist arts,
Try releasing your grip upon the golden steps.

Tipping back the cup of Huayang, I drink thrice more;
Riding my dragon at dusk, I descend the southern crag.
My brows bristle as I strike my sword, leaving trails of starlight;
My robes, draped over clouds, gather emerald mist.
The golden liquid transforms into rain and dew;
Returning to the Jade Capital, I age like pines and cedars.
Once, I used an iron mirror to illuminate spirits and ghosts—
Crackling thunder searched the fiery depths of the pool.

The iron mirror smelts gold as flames fill the sky;
In the jade-green pool, the dragon rests beneath the setting sun.
The qilin’s intent harmonizes with heaven and earth;
The dew’s mechanism binds sun and moon.
A three-foot sword lies across the banks of twin streams;
A five-spiked crown adorns the lord of a hundred spirits.
At leisure, I don robes of feathers within an immortal’s grotto;
Alone, I don golden lotus shoes to craft creation’s work.

Following the karmic tide, I drift and sink at will,
My heart like water, like clouds—a single expanse.
Two scrolls of Daoist scripture, a three-foot sword,
A flowering staff, a seven-stringed zither.
The elixir within my gourd, I bestow upon others;
New verses in my breast, I recite to guests.
A single taste eternally adds a thousand years of life;
A single grain of cinnabar transmutes a pound of gold.

Zither, sword, wine, and chess—dragon, crane, and tiger—
Carefree and untethered, water without sorrow.
At leisure, I ride a white deer to wander the Three Isles;
In boredom, I drive a green ox to view the Ten Continents.
From afar, I watch the bright moon rise over the emerald cave;
High upon the green mountain, I hide amidst flowing clouds.
Should men of this age desire the same,
Let them abandon fame and profit, fleeting splendor.

Within the Purple Ultimate Palace, I know my own path—
I personally whet my divine sword to pierce the returning *fei*.
First, I dispatch the Jade Lad to open the southern hall;
Next, I send the Azure Dragon into the Purple Tenuity.
Nine tripods of yellow sprouts nestle auspicious phoenixes;
A single immortal’s frame nurtures sacred lingzhi.
Penglai is no place for ordinary men—
I fear only fools will leak the world’s secrets.

Turning back, I finally emerge from the dust;
Creation’s work lies solely in man.
Had I earlier cast off the celestial dragon’s earthly net,
How would I know the White Tiger’s emergence from true nature?
Endless is the path—who detains me?
Silent and wordless, I naturally unite with the divine.
Striking my sword in the deep of night, where do I return?
Clad in stars and moonlight, I cleave the qilin.

Spring wanes, idly passing fallen blossoms;
Each time I dance with my sword, I sigh.
Ever anxious that the white sun’s light and time are fleeting,
Ever resentful that the blue sky’s road is distant.
My original intent seeks neither fame nor profit;
My fundamental heart admires only water and mist.
Of the world’s myriad floating and sinking affairs,
Who among the enlightened can compare to my family?

The sun for harmony, the moon for cinnabar—
The lords of Hua and Xia behold with mortal eyes.
Benevolence and righteousness differ as Hu and Yue;
Worldly sentiments are as difficult as Tai and Heng.
After refining the Eight Immortals, the bell’s spirit is wondrous;
Forged across the four seas, it chills the gall to fear.
Laughing, I point out ten thousand injustices—
Riding my dragon, wielding my sword, I guard the ninefold gates.

Since parting, six eastern winds have blown over Luoyang;
Drunken eyes, drowsy emotions—indolent and unyielding.
Shaking heaven and earth, my golden sword roars;
Smelting sun and moon, the jade furnace glows red.
My staff sways over the three thousand kings of Chu’s domains;
My crane soars through the ten thousand layers of Qin’s mists.
To report to the immortal of Jin City:
We shall meet again in spring at Kuaiji Peak.

Before refining the returning elixir, first refine the heart;
Only when the elixir is complete does one perceive the Dao’s profound origin.

Each leaves behind coins for wine and revelry—
Who would believe you lack the elixir to transmute gold?
Within the grotto, wind and thunder return to your grasp;
In the gourd, sun and moon rest within your breast.

The work of immortals—how few can comprehend it—
Cultivating nature, prolonging life, one hums to oneself.
An iron ox plows the earth, sowing golden coins;
A stone is carved, and youths string them into strands.

A single grain of millet holds a hidden world;
In a two-sheng cauldron, mountains and rivers boil.
The white-haired elder’s brows trail to the ground;
The blue-eyed foreign boy points his hand to the sky.
If you grasp this mystery within the mystery,
Beyond this mystery, no mystery remains.

The Winnowing Basket star and the Proud Host descend from the endless sky—
How could the mortal realm not stand in awe?
The dragon emerges from the water, its scales and armor complete;
The crane soars into the heavens, its feathers whole.

Amid the dust, you teach a thousand eyes to see;
Yet in the world, few know the *Erya*’s refined verses.
It is but the ledger of fortune for the common folk—
How could such subtle wonders lightly be passed on?

At leisure, I swing my arms and enter the Gate of Heaven,
Brushing my sleeves, I slowly gather the colored clouds.
Silent, I look down upon the Yellow Valley’s child;
With a smile, I bow to the Purple Radiance Lord.

I intend to ascend the Jade Palace and pay homage to the Metal Mother,
Then visit Yingzhou to behold the solar wheel.
Just then, Chang’e prepares a feast—
The jade nectar, newly brewed, steams with fragrance.

Once I followed Liu and Ruan, drunk in Peach Blossom Spring;
Unconcerned with debts for wine in the mortal world.
A hempen robe serves as collateral for now—
When the sun returns from the nine heavens, it shall be repaid.

Phoenix-down robes are not to be prized;
Even fox-fur garments cannot compare.
This is the world’s priceless treasure—
No need to test it in the fire’s trial.

Recalling past affairs, I sigh with pity:
I once read the thirteenth scroll of the immortals’ scriptures.
When Empress Wu died, she was but a maiden;
When Chen Yu perished, he remained a youth.
Two wheels of sun and moon bear their burdens;
Nine mountains and rivers rest upon a single shoulder.

By day, no one speaks of such tidings—
A gourd of spring wine leaves me drunk and content.
With sleeves hanging loose, I stride proudly above the world’s dust,
My gourd holding the fruits of many journeys.
Fame and profit, beyond the body, are not the Dao—
Before the Gate of Dragon and Tiger, discern the truth.

Awakening from a dream, my soul visits the Court of Heat;
For years, my traces have hidden in the dust of the world.
In Huayin’s market, we meet again—
Not the usual wandering peddler of medicines.

Ten thousand scrolls of immortal scriptures, a three-foot zither—
Liu An recognized me as a kindred spirit.
At my staff’s tip, a gourd of wine;
In my furnace, cinnabar transforms into countless grains of gold.

Bored, I sleep drunk at the crossroads;
At leisure, I fish in the heart of Dongting.
Who among those we meet could recognize us?
I fear that if we soar into the heavens, none could find us.

Once I battled Chiyou before the Jade Throne,
Six dragons high in their chariot, phoenix bells ringing.
Behind the Tathāgata’s carriage, I followed the golden drums;
Beside the Yellow Emperor’s banner, I wore an iron crown.

Drunk, I darkened the black beard of the Three Isles;
Enraged, I drew my frost-edged sword, chilling the Ten Continents.
After the age of the Xuanyuan’s dominion,
I hid deep in the ravines, long sought but never found.

My horns and scales resound like a bell in the azure waves;
My face is like ice, my bones like pine.
The treasured sword in its scabbard often roars;
The golden hammer in my sleeve stirs the wind.

When drinking, I am the life of the gathering;
When reciting poems, I join in perfect harmony.
Next year, I shall surely attend the Penglai assembly,
Riding a fierce and multicolored dragon.

Immortals enter the golden gates at dusk;
The gates of generals and ministers stand in the Jade Capital.
Yet if the grotto holds no fine sights,
It is for pity of the world’s living multitudes.

My heart’s zither harmonizes with the wandering crane;
My sword in its scabbard awaits the slaying of whales.
Between advance and retreat, neither path seems right—
I rely on you to point the way forward.

The Nine Tripods boil a single grain of cinnabar,
The fire’s timing naturally unfurls the child’s flower.
Stars illuminate the blue lotus seeds;
Sun and moon conceal the white horse’s teeth.

Seven returns refine the emerald dew;
Nine reversions bring forth the crimson mist.
If one seizes and consumes the Mystic Pearl,
The path to the Three Isles is not far.

*Record of the Venerable Lü, Scroll Five* (ends)

**Art and Literature Record**

**Miscellaneous Writings: Ten Entries**

**Three Poems on Cultivating the Self**

Life is as urgent as a thread,
Swift as an arrow’s flight up and down.
Recognize the primordial spirit—
After midnight, before noon, refine it without fail.
Roam freely out, return freely in,
For heaven, earth, and humanity share this one truth.
Once attained, never lose it—
Lost, you’ll seek in vain forevermore.
Pity the tombs in desolate fields,
Where the dead of ages past knew no end.

*(One version omits the last two lines.)*

Amidst the splendor of fleeting flowers,
Worldly affairs drift endlessly.
Those who grasp it hold the primal qi,
Those who lose it fade into the three springs’ gloom.

The supreme medicine dwells where the dragon resides,
The tiger guards the dragon’s palace.
When dragon and tiger merge as one,
Discern the path of dimness and profound obscurity.
Great lightning flashes—yet the spirit remains untouched,
Thunder roars fiercely—yet the spirit knows no fear.
Abandon that, seize this—*(one version reads: Abandon that splendor, seize this truth)*
To sustain the work of enduring vision,
This is the marvel of transmuting the spirit.

First lodge in the child, then seek the mother.
Take the head as the foundation, capture harmony and rectify the grasp.
Water subdues fire, the dragon leads the tiger.
Attained between the brows, it first responds to the Mysterious Female.
Thunder’s startle, lightning’s vanishing—
All belong to the Yellow Canopy’s domain *(or: "within")*.
Golden liquid, jade nectar—
All treasures of the Elixir Pool.
Laozi’s art is wholly contained herein.

Alas! Gold and jade fill the hall,
Yet none can keep them.

**Three-Character Poem**

This Dao is no ordinary Dao.
The root of life, the aperture of life and death.
Spoken, it seems foul; practiced, it is wondrous.
All despise it, all bark at it.
The great key lies in inversion.
Do not shun filth, do not calculate.
Once grasped, its effects appear at once.
Heaven and Earth unite—*(the crow bears the omen)*.
Mouth to mouth, aperture to aperture.
Swallow it into the belly, and you’ll know for yourself.
The sprouts of medicine are fresh, the sign of the primordial.
Examine between the brows, follow the reverse path.
The essence of moisture nurtures, naturally continuing the line.
When these two remain, only then is it sublime.
To practice it makes others cry out.
Qi must be firm, spirit must not dissipate.
If you do not practice, you’ll age in vain.
Recognize the truth, and the old return to youth.
Those who do not understand, do not speak of it.
This small method accords with the Great Dao.
Essence, qi, and spirit are the elixir of immortality *(read as "essential")*.
Preserved in stillness, repaid in clarity.
Ride the phoenix and simurgh, listen to Heaven’s music.

**One Hundred-Character Chant on the Inner Elixir**

Nurture qi, forget words, and guard;
Subdue the heart to act without acting.
In movement and stillness, know the ancestor—
With nothing to do, whom else would you seek?
The true constant must respond to things,
Yet in responding, avoid delusion.
Not deluded, the nature abides;
Nature abiding, qi naturally returns.
Qi returning, the elixir forms itself;
Within the crucible, Kan and Li unite.
Yin and yang generate reversal,
Universal transformation—a single thunderclap.
White clouds ascend to the crown,
Sweet dew sprinkles Mount Sumeru.
Drink the wine of longevity yourself—
Who else could know this freedom?
Sit and listen to the stringless melody,
Understand clearly the mechanism of creation.
These twenty lines in all
Are indeed the ladder to heaven.

**One Hundred-Character Chant on the Outer Elixir**

Lead and mercury dwell in the crucible,
Refined into a priceless pearl.
All comes down to two words,
Resolving the writings of ten thousand households.
Use lead yet do not use lead—
Without lead, mercury will not return.
Master the theft of black within lead,
Then the cinnabar in stone is surely dead.
The great medicine has no head,
The golden elixir’s cauldron has no ears.
No need for other medicines—
Lead and mercury regulate each other.
Regulating, they become husband and wife,
Naturally achieving harmony.
A hundred days of fire talismans,
And the crucible contains heaven and earth.
A year completes the great elixir,
Its power then manifests in the world.
Those who use lead are countless,
But how many value true lead?

**Admonition to the World**

A speck of goodness aids others.
A speck of evil—refrain from committing it.
Clothing and food follow fate—
Be content, and joy comes naturally.
What does it matter what life is?
Why consult divination?
Deceiving others brings misfortune;
Forgiving others brings blessing.
The eyes of heaven see clearly—
Retribution comes swiftly.
Heed my words,
And gods and ghosts will submit.

**Lyrics in Mixed Meter**

Fallen and destitute, fallen and destitute,
Sleeping in villages by night, wandering cities by day.
At leisure, I roam green mountains;
When weary, I sell elixirs in the marketplace.
The money earned is not hoarded—
I buy fine wine and pour it myself.
Drunk, my chanting stirs gods and ghosts,
Carefree as the sun sinks in the west.

**Six-Character Poem**

Spring warms, half the flowers bloom,
I wander leisurely upon the rocks.
Alone I carry the jade rhythm and elixir script,
Strolling idly over green moss and emerald moss.
Slept nine years in an ancient grotto,
Drank flowing radiance by the thousand cups.
When meeting others, speak not of other matters—
Point to the white clouds coming and going.

**Four-Character Self-Narration**

A Tang dynasty *jinshi*,
Today an immortal.
Feet treading purple mist,
I return to the grotto-heaven.
Moon bright, wind clear,
A single iron flute sounds.
Looking back at the mountains,
No trace remains across the four seas.

**Two Couplets Inscribed at Jingfu Temple**

**Nine Songs**

**Song of Enlightenment at Ezhou**

A carefree wanderer across the skies,
I chanced upon the Double Ninth in late autumn.
Dark clouds spread across the vast heavens,
Sweet rains nourished all things without end.
Muddy roads kept me from leaving my door,
When suddenly I heard a neighbor speak of elixir arts.
I asked if he would transmit them—
A single word of assent, and no difficulty remained.
Several strange texts came into my hands,
One night I lit a lamp and read without cease.
By dawn, the sun was high, and I had finished—
Unaware, I was drunk as if in a trance.
In that trance, I saw something appear,
Shaped like the sun, bright as a sudden sail.
It said it was the essence of cinnabar,
Fit to refine mortal substance in the crucible.
Mortal substance cannot transform into truth—
To transform truth, one must obtain the true within.
No need for bismuth, no need for mercury—
The returning elixir must be planted in the furnace.
The mystery within mystery is called true bismuth,
Yet when using bismuth, one does not use it.
Sometimes called dragon, sometimes tiger,
Sometimes infant boy, sometimes wondrous girl.
A single name for cinnabar encompasses a thousand forms,
Yet within the one, there is one that is the elixir’s mother.

Do not kindle fire, do not freeze water—
Refine and temper with utmost care.
Wait until the tiger roars atop the shattered peak,
When the black dragon seizes the dark pearl to play.

The dragon swallows the mysterious treasure and suddenly soars,
But the soaring dragon is caught by me to ride.
With a single breath, I ascend to return to the Azure Vault,
Where the Azure Vault stretches boundless, without east or west.
No dawn, no night, no years, no months,
No cold, no heat, no four seasons.
Only when cultivating to the realm of non-action
Do I begin to sense the wondrous and the strange.

*Knocking the Hexagrams Song*
A drifting wanderer between Han’s end and Tang’s realm,
Thus the knocking of hexagrams remains unfathomable.
Unrestrained in all directions, without barrier,
Stillness is non-action, movement is form.

I drink wine, I eat meat,
Yet hold fast to rouge and powder, cutting off lust.
I practice meditation, chanting verses of rouge and powder,
Upholding precepts while wine and meat fill my belly.
Form is medicine, wine is emolument—
Within wine and form, there is no constraint.
Only through flowers and wine was long life awakened,
Drinking wine with flowers, even spirits and ghosts weep.

Do not break precepts, do not transgress lust—
Breaking precepts, true suchness sinks;
Transgressing lust, the treasure of long life is lost.
Only those with Dao-power may attain it,
And those with Dao-power are true free spirits.
Wine is a good friend, flowers a companion.
In the streets of flowers and willows, seek the true person—
The true person is found only in the flower-street meal.
Pluck flowers, wear them, drink the wine of long life,
Revering non-action, the Dao naturally flourishes.
Let the deluded masses bark and jeer—
The immortal flowers and immortal wine are the immortal land.
Arriving at this land, one is no ordinary guest,
Where wondrous girls and infant boys birth joy.
Within the cave, flowers of all seasons are ever plucked,
Each flower knits the elixir of long life.
The elixir of long life is plucked from the flower’s heart,
Layer upon layer of flower-medicine in radiant spring.
Yet people of this age do not grasp the principle within flowers—
A single secret of heaven’s mechanism is worth ten thousand gold.

Grateful to heaven and earth, moved by the empty void,
I met an immortal master, my ancestral lineage.
Whispering in my ear, the profound and wondrous intent,
He lifted me to Penglai’s first peak.
The first peak is an immortal thing,
Where only golden flowers bloom in trance.
Mouth to mouth, the transmission leaves no written trace,
Yet the numinous root is strengthened to the marrow and bone.
Strengthening marrow and bone, refining the numinous root,
Petal by petal, peach blossoms bring spring to the cave.
In seven sevens, white tigers are reared in pairs,
In eight eights, green dragons total one catty.

True father and mother escort the original palace,
Wood-mother and metal-father, their natures inherently gentle.
Within the twelve palaces, the toad’s spirit appears,
As earthly souls descend and heavenly souls alight.
Lead first formed, mercury first born,
Jade crucible and golden tripod yet unheated.
One husband, one wife, mirroring heaven and earth,
One boy, one girl, uniting Qian and Kun.
Geng must be born, Jia must be born—
When Jia and Geng are born, the Dao begins to sprout.
Plucking the root of heaven and the marrow of earth,
White snow and yellow sprouts grow of themselves.

Lead also begets mercury, mercury also begets—
Mercury and lead are refined together in one place.
This refining is not of essence and fluid,
But the essence of heaven and earth, Qian and Kun, sun and moon.
The Yellow Dame matches them to perfect union,
Transmitting the secret without error, mouth to mouth.
The Eight Trigrams and Two Origins rely entirely on mercury,
The Five Phases and Four Images how could they leave lead?

Lead begets mercury, mercury begets lead—
Seizing the power of Qian and Kun’s creation.
In the profound and obscure, trance is born,
From trance and obscurity, a mass is formed.
Nature must be empty, intent must be focused,
Lest the monkey-mind climb recklessly.
When the flower-dew first opens, touch is strictly forbidden,
Sealed within the earthen crucible, do not add or remove.
Within the jade crucible, the civil fire refines,
Through the twelve hours, guard the One.
At this time, the Yellow Path unites yin and yang,
The three natures and original palace suffer no leakage.

When qi moves, the true fire tempers—
Do not let the dark pearl leave the precious hall.
Increasing the fire’s measure, guard against danger,
For the first nine, the hidden dragon must not be refined.
The subtle workings of fire and the knife’s edge transform,
The yellow sprouts of the great earth grow everywhere.
Within the Five Phases’ number, one yang is born,
The twenty-four qi arrayed like a banquet of pearls.
When the fire is sufficient and the medicine complete,
The dragon’s roar and tiger’s howl resound.
Of three leads, only one lead is achieved,
The golden fruit and immortal sprout have yet to appear.

Reinstall the furnace, reestablish the tripod,
Riding the tiger, mounting the dragon, departing the mortal realm.
When the sun’s essence first appears and the moon’s radiance congeals,
The two eights unite in Ren and Bing.
Dragon-mercury binds, tiger-lead forms—
Penglai is but a short journey away.
Kun-lead and Qian-mercury are the ancestors of the golden elixir,
Dragon-lead and tiger-mercury are most spiritually attuned.
Only when this principle is grasped is completion achieved,
As thirty thousand divine dragons guard the crystal.
Guard the time, fix the day, clarify the talisman’s moment,
Devote the heart solely to reverent intent.

When black lead is refined and true essence purified,
A single clash settles great peace.
The three chariots transport the pearl treasures,
Returning to the precious treasury, naturally attaining numinosity.
Heavenly spirits protect, earthly deities welcome,
Merging Qian and Kun, the essence of sun and moon.
With a single roar, the tiger emerges from its den,
Phoenixes dance and simurghs fly from the golden city.
Cinnabar paired with mercury in balance,
A band of rosy clouds arrays before the Great Clarity.
From the lead pool, golden light bursts forth,
Mercury-fire flows like pearls into the imperial capital.

Beyond the union of dragon and tiger, hold fullness,
As the sagely walks and the numinous flies within the precious vase.
Within a single hour, the golden elixir is achieved,
Ascending to the golden gates as purple clouds arise.
The immortal peach ripens—pluck and consume it,
As the myriad transformations pay homage, heaven and earth rejoice.
With fasting and vigil, await the birth of one yang,
Then advance the Zhou Heaven, fathoming the *Can Tong Qi*.
Fathoming the *Can Tong Qi*, refine the golden elixir,
As water and fire steam through the barrier gates.
Nurturing the embryo for two months, the divine elixir forms—
How could a man’s pregnancy be ordinary?
The inner elixir is complete, the outer elixir achieved,
Inner and outer join in harmonious union.
Forming a single pellet of purple-golden pill,
Transforming and soaring through heaven and earth for eternity.

The elixir enters the belly, no common thing—
Yin is stripped away, transforming into pure yang.
Ascending and transcending as a guest of the Three Clarities,
Name fulfilled, merit accomplished, reaching the highest heavens.
The guest of the Three Clarities mounts a cloud-borne chariot,
Riding the phoenix, soaring through the empyrean into the Great Void.
Such carefree joy and delight—
Roaming the Three Realms, most pure and wondrous.
Above the Great Void, the cultivator of truth,
Bright and round, without a single thing.
Without a single thing, only the Dao is manifest,
As the true countenance of the perfected emerges from the five directions.
Immortal boys and girls welcome with colored clouds,
Within the Palace of Five Lights, the true decree is transmitted.

The transmission of the true decree speaks of hidden truths,
Only through refining true lead and mercury’s essence.
The voices of enlightenment melt like ice,
While heretical asuras shrink back in terror.

Touching withered bones, they rise and take form—
Trust in the Dao, and heaven’s ladder lies flat as your palm.
Nine generations of ancestors attain liberation,
Who would envy the fleeting splendor of wealth and rank?

Seek the resolute and the worthy,
To join in the crucible and transform the mortal frame.
If one clings to riches or hoards treasures,
Ten thousand immortals will refuse to come.

The cultivator of truth does not speak idly,
For each reckless word shortens heaven’s span.
Through countless kalpas like grains of sand, the Dao remains unachieved,
And the seven apertures of the eyes burst with blood.

The poor and determined vow earnestly,
To lift all mortal streams to transcendence.
Together they ascend to the Penglai immortal assembly,
Where worldly suffering knows no end.

In this fleeting dust-bound life, reflect deeply—
Within the cavern’s realm, heaven and earth, sun and moon endure.
With steadfast resolve and苦心 for three or two years,
A lifespan of ten thousand kalpas stretches boundless.

Attaining the sacred Dao, the true and constant is revealed,
Tigers, rhinos, blades, and weapons can no longer harm.
Water, fire, and dragons bring no injury,
Clapping hands in the celestial palace, they laugh with delight.

Such wondrous and subtle merits—
Yet who among men would truly seek them?
Fools cling to lust and wealth,
Thus immortals refuse to summon them.

The true and perfect Dao does not choose its vessel,
Nor does it favor high or low, rich or poor.
Even princes and nobles must shed their splendor,
And grind away their sharp edges.

If anger is not purged and desires remain unchanged,
One plunges into the wheel of rebirth, the sea of suffering.
Though gold and jade pile like mountains,
Immortals turn cold and indifferent.

Fame is not noble—only the Dao is supreme,
Passed down through sages and worthies to their descendants.
Adorned with gold, riding fine steeds,
Yet they vanish like dust in a crack of time.

Dust in a crack, a spark in stone—
Why fix the heart on such fleeting schemes?
Through ceaseless suffering, none can be called back,
As they scramble for profit and fame like a boiling cauldron.

Like a boiling cauldron, they sink forever,
Losing the Dao, deluded by illusion, bound by karma’s root.
But one who levels the thorns in the heart,
I shall reveal the celestial mechanism to you.

Life must be transmitted, nature must be awakened,
Entering sagehood and transcending the mortal lies within your grasp.
Few tread the path to the Three Clarities,
While the gates of beasts teem with those who rush in.

Turn away from worldly admiration,
Guard well the mechanism of nature and life.
If even one is lacking, the blossom will not bloom,
Clinging to waves and foam, you will lose the way.

To cultivate nature without cultivating life—
This is the gravest error in practice.
To cultivate ancestral nature without refining the elixir,
Through ten thousand kalpas, the yin spirit struggles to attain sagehood.

To grasp life’s school but neglect ancestral nature,
Is like a mirror without its precious reflective surface.
Though one’s lifespan equals heaven and earth, they remain a fool,
Holding wealth and power like a steward without true authority.

To cultivate both nature and life is profound and mysterious,
Sailing the great waves of the ocean’s depths in a dharma boat.
Seizing the dragon’s head alive and whole,
Only then does one know the master craftsman’s skill is no empty boast.

**Secret Song**
Seek it, yet it cannot be seen;
When it comes, it is no longer seen.

Unseen, unseen—
Your primal face remains unseen.
It once soared within fire,
Yet appears within water.

The path is not distant,
Neither body nor mind clings—
Yet who knows the tortoise that returns yin,
The hawk that restores yang?

When encountering, one meets the person;
When attaining, one grasps the spirit.
Twelve thousand cycles of sixty years—
This flask of flowing rosy dawn endures eternally.

Flowing rosy dawn, flowing rosy dawn,
All belongs to the family of original nature.
Hungry, feast on the essence of the sun;
Thirsty, drink the radiance of the moon.

In the year of *jiazi* and *dingchou*,
I shall shatter the great bulrush gate for you.

**Song of the Great Elixir Directly Pointed**
The Three Pure Palaces hide atop Kunlun’s peak,
Sun and moon’s light floats, raising purple mist.
Pools and ponds brim, jade liquid churning;
Pavilions and terraces layer, circulating numinous springs.

The Green Dragon rides fire, mercury as its ore;
The White Tiger surges waves, mercury as its lead.
To obtain the Kan male, seek a mate;
One must rely on the Li female to forge the bond.

The Yellow Dame devises a thousand schemes,
The golden crucible opens into a single lotus bloom.
The Woman of Virtue holds the crow at the left,
The General wears the hare to guard the west.

The Black Tortoise crouches beneath the red furnace,
The Vermilion Bird perches before the radiant pavilion.
Then, calming the spirit, one glimpses the reflection—
After three cycles, the work is done, riding clouds to plow.

**Song of the Valley Spirit**
I have an abdomen, an empty valley’s void,
Speak of the Dao, it is and yet is not.
Speak of its non-being—it cannot be abandoned;
Speak of its being—it cannot be dwelled in.

Valley! Valley! Profound and wondrous,
Spirit! Spirit! The true Great Dao.
Preserve it, guard it, and gain the name of immortality;
Cultivate it, refine it, and earn the title of transcendent.

The spirit attains the One and becomes numinous,
The valley attains the One and becomes full.
If one can hold to the One,
This alone is longevity.

Longevity is not far,
Yet apart from the body, it cannot be seen.
If the refining’s work is complete,
Naturally, mortal bones transform.

The Valley Spirit never dies—this is the Mysterious Female’s gate,
Entrance and exit, ceaseless, the Dao as if present.
Refinement must occur at midnight’s *zi* hour,
The River Chariot bears the load to Kunlun’s peak.

The dragon chants, the tiger roars,
Wind and clouds converge as the Yellow Dame cries out.
Within the fire, the Crone holds her grace;
Turning back, the Infant beneath the water charms.

Infant and Crone meet the Yellow Dame,
Child and mother reunite, their wills in harmony.
Twelve gates of golden halls and jade chambers,
The Metal Elder and Wooden Mother now pass through.

After the layered gates, the secure barrier locks,
Inspecting the Dipper and Ox, first apply the fire.
Advancing the fire to dissolve yin, the first yang emerges,
The thousand-year immortal peach first bears fruit.

The eastern shore of Qujiang binds the golden crow in flight,
The western shore’s pure palace gleams with the jade hare’s light.
Crow and hare return to the peak’s summit,
In the furnace, the Maiden sheds her blue robe.

Shedding the blue robe reveals the pristine body,
The Infant leads her into the layered curtains.
After ten months of deep affection, a boy is born,
Said to be ever-living, never dying.

I urge you to refine, I urge you to cultivate—
Seek the undying Valley Spirit here.
Here, awaken to the subtle and profound,
And with you, ascend in broad daylight to Yingzhou.

**Song of the Brick**
The brick follows the rain’s erosion,
Yet it has never endured water and fire.
If it had passed through water and fire to become brick,
It would remain in the world for ten thousand years.

Its edges firm and intact, never to decay,
Struck, its resonant tone fit for carving.
Even common water and fire achieve this,
What among the myriad things can compare in durability?

On the path of cultivation, how many there are,
Who exhaust years refining and nurturing, wasting spirit.
Unaware they have never endured water and fire,
Impermanence suddenly arrives at their door.

Failing to awaken, never repenting,
Even in death, they still borrow essence and marrow.
Upholding the right thought is arduous,
One misstep, and the human form becomes another kind.

Have you not seen the wealthy Zheng of Luoyang,
Who spoke of the golden elixir as if deaf and blind?
Clinging to delusion, unaware of the truth of cultivation,
How could he know the hidden harmony of creation’s work?

Have you not seen Zhang, the Prefect of Jiujiang,
Who consumed medicine, lost his sight, and withered his spirit?
Not knowing the Returning Elixir has no substance,
He recklessly ingested metals and stones—how foolish!

Have you not seen Zhao, the Privy Councilor of Sanqu,
Who studied Chan, became a ghost, and never understood?
Where lies the completion of the outer form?
Clever words and swift debates are ultimately unreal.

The brick follows the rain’s erosion,
Just like these few in their cultivation.
The great man transcends awakened nature,
Exhausting the gates of emptiness without seeking verification.

Fu Xi transmitted the Dao to this day,
Exhausting principle, fulfilling nature, and attaining life.
To fulfill life—what is the original source?
First recognize Kan and Li, and the Four Directions.

Kan and Li are the true eternal home,
Those who see this transcend the mundane and enter sagehood.
Kan is the tiger, Li is the dragon,
The two bodies originally dwell in one palace.

Dragon swallows, tiger devours, abiding within,
Separation and union, floating and sinking, beginning and end.
Stripping and returning, negating and affirming,
Advancing and retreating, coming and going, the union is certain.

Waxing and full, waning and empty, they match in pairs,
The immortal deeply enters the crystal palace,
Drinking fermented nectar, ever clearer and richer.
After a thousand days of ingestion, the work is complete,
Golden ribs and jade bones, the body already light.

This vision belongs only to oneself,
Ascending early to pay homage to the Three Pures.
The Three Pure Sacred Seats are also mine,
Originally, they only seize the essence of heaven and earth.

Drinking common wine, eating rank and fishy foods,
Nourishing the original harmony, ever more abundant.
Naturally fusing and congealing, turning luminous,
Transforming into pearls, flying to the Jade Capital.
In an instant, six years without hunger,
Blood transmutes into white cream, the body indestructible.

Not eating is the true fasting,
True qi steams and strengthens the limbs.
Having ceased eating, surpassing a hundred eons,
Mouth and nose no longer breathe common breath.
The true person breathes through the heels, the common through the throat,
From this, true and common stand on either side.

Thus, one attains the leakless body,
Fetal breathing in the cinnabar field stirs true fire.
Laozi henceforth is called the Infant,
The fire’s regimen spans nine years.

Preserving form to dwell in the world, unaware of spring,
Suddenly, the Heavenly Gate opens atop the crown.
The true person emerges with great spiritual powers,
From this, celestial immortals may offer congratulations.

The sages of the Three Teachings share one gate,
The deluded labor in vain—why exhaust yourselves?
Those with insight cherish life,
The embodied never truly perish.

Alas for the foolish, who vainly mount empty discourse,
Drifting without rule or end, trapped in cycles—when will they break free?
Students, students, search carefully,
And you must delve into the ancient gold and jade.

Gold and jade intermingle without reckoning years,
Wondrous within wondrous, mysterious within mysterious.
Encouraging Niu Sheng and Xiahou Ge, the two scholars:
Two scholars—yet not scholars,
Not scholars, but immortals in the making.

Within the land of China, they met in person,
Gazing heavenward, their eyes alight with laughter.
Once more, turning back.

Crane-like in form, tortoise-like in bones,
Dragon’s chant, tiger’s visage.
I have utmost words to exhort you,
Would that you, sir, neither doubt nor guess.

Simply bask in the sun, breathe the wind,
Swallow rain, exhale thunder,
Fire lodged in the hidden palace, water aiding the cinnabar terrace.
Metal and wood exchange, earth returns to its place,
Lead and mercury part, revealing the embryo.

Red blood transforms, white milk flows,
Light penetrates the apertures, stirring the hundred bones.
Now coiled, now unfurled,
At the sound of laughter—ha ha!—the child gasps yet does not die.

The belly empty, fasting evermore,
Repaying fame and profit with wild song and drunken dance,
Repaying wealth and honor with hempen sandals and plain straw shoes,
Asking the year’s cycle—why keep count?

See the mulberry fields turn to yellow dust,
Green mountains and white clouds make a fine abode.
I urge you: go home, go home.

To Hermit Liu of White Dragon Cave:
Jade flees, gold flies—both luminaries rush,
First blooms the flower, then comes autumn frost.
Vainly boast of a thousand years of wealth and longevity,
Yet it is but a lightning flash amid the clouds.

How swift that lightning flash!
A hundred years amount to but thirty thousand days.
Within them, cold and heat alternately torment,
Unaware, the youthful face fades in darkness.

Though children and grandchildren fill your sight,
Affection and love only entangle further.
When essence is exhausted and the body withers,
Who can teach them to briefly preserve their countenance?

With no means to extend life,
One must surrender the body to flowing waters.
Look upon the sages of old—
How many knew how to remain in the world?

Yet there is a way to remain in the world,
Only because men of this age mismeasure.
They scramble to the mountains in search of herbs,
Refining lead, controlling mercury, concocting cinnabar.

Concocting cinnabar is no trifling matter—
One must seek crimson blood within the Kan trigram,
Take it to the Li position to temper yin essence,
Harmonizing and blending at the proper time.

The proper time requires a matchmaker:
The Gold Elder and the Maiden wed.
The Gold Elder loves to ride the White Tiger,
The Maiden ever mounts the Crimson Dragon.

The tiger sits quietly by the autumn river,
The dragon stirs its body in the deep pool.
The two beasts meet in battle,
Waves surging like a boiling cauldron.

The Yellow Matriarch and Ding Lao lend their might,
Shaking the gods and spirits of heaven and earth.
In an instant, the battle ends, clouds disperse,
Planting a mysterious pearl in the mud’s depths.

From this, roots and sprouts gradually grow,
Tended with timely irrigation, embracing true essence.
After ten months, the embryo is shed, swallowed into the mouth,
Suddenly, the mortal body is imbued with spirit.

This matter is rare in the world,
Not known to ordinary men.
If in past lives you lacked immortal bones,
How could you easily encounter it?

The Golden Elixir should be refined at once,
For time flies swift as an arrow.
To catch fish, one must weave a net—
Why not still the heart and refine lead?

Lest the candle be snuffed out by the wind,
The six paths of rebirth make heaven hard to reach.
Lately, men of the world are full of deceit,
All donning plain robes to call themselves Daoists.

Ask them what metal and wood are—
They fall silent, mute as the afflicted.
Yet they claim to practice qi absorption and fasting,
Claiming other paths and distant roads.

Have they not seen the *Song of Breaking Delusion* by Lord Yin,
Where the Taiyi’s ear-containment method is strongest?
Do not fault my words for being too wild or coarse,
Only because men of this age are hard to discern.

Only when your heart aligns with mine
Dare I pour out my heart to you.

Inscribed on the Gate of Master Huang’s Hermitage on Tongwu Mountain:
I possess words most mysterious within the mysterious,
Wandering the eight directions, nowhere to speak—
Like drifting clouds, they float to Ningsun,
Where I meet you, sir, in the profound.

I know you are a solitary cloud’s traveler,
About to speak of the subtle and formless,
The root source of the great Dao.

I urge you to seek the truth within—
There is one, divided into three and five,
Originally nameless—cold spring’s trickling,
Qi flowing ceaselessly,
Rising through Kunlun, returning to purple float.

Sinking and rising, entering the central palace,
The four images and five phases all manifest,
Green Dragon seizes the White Tiger,
Auspicious winds rise, sweet dew descends,
Lead congeals true mercury, cinnabar forms,
A single wheel of fire reigns supreme.

Having cultivated the true, be steadfast,
Able to turn heaven and earth, float mountains and seas.
Moving through heaven and earth, none can know,
Transforming ghosts and spirits, none perceive.

After a thousand mornings, the purple-gold body is forged,
Thereupon the spirit is perfected, returning to simplicity.

Huang, scholar Huang,
Having cultivated the true, do so early.
Among men, when will worldly affairs end?

Greed for fame, greed for profit, love of gold’s abundance—
For their sake, the body ages and withers.
Now I urge you with sorrowful heart,
Consider, sir, the vigor of life.

Lest the great limit arrive at your body,
And you drift once more into birth and extinction.

I leave these words to express my intent.
When next we meet,
I shall surely press you further.
Do not waver from your initial resolve,
Cherish well, cherish well.

Eighteen Fisherman’s Songs:
Entering samadhi.

Close your eyes to conceal the true, your spirit’s thoughts congeal,
In the boundless dark, behold your origin.
Vast and dim, indistinct,
The mysterious vision arises—all is emptiness.

**First Nine:**
The Great Dao has ever belonged to nature,
In an empty hall, sit in stillness, guarding the mechanism.
The Three Fields’ treasure,
Ever preserved,
The Red Emperor sits clearly in the vast cold.

**Mysterious Workings:**
Sun and moon intertwine, racing day and night,
At Kunlun’s summit, the cosmos is fixed.
Within the true mirror,
Truly worth discussing,
The crimson dawn’s glow quietly inquires.

**Spirit’s Efficacy:**
In vagueness, seize it—it comes naturally,
Stealing creation’s work within the divine crucible.
Fire refines,
Passing through yin and yang,
To congeal the elixir.

**Bathing:**
At the gates of Mao and You, the time of action,
The Red Dragon dips into the jade-clear clouds, thin as mist,
Rain falls lightly,
Revealing the demon’s form, skin like snow.

**Prolonging Life:**
At Zi and Wu, constantly feast on the essence of sun and moon,
The gate of the mysterious pass opens and remains so—
Live thus your whole life,
Carefully refining yin and yang.

**Auspicious Crucible:**
Convergence arises from the house of Wu and Ji,
No need for gold and mercury—
This alone forms the cinnabar,
As yin and yang reverse, its hue transforms.

**Attaining Life:**
Standing in the Three Powers, belonging to the Five Phases,
Where yin and yang unite, dragons soar,
Tigers rage,
Spitting forth a divine pearl, each contends.

**Brilliance:**
The Four Symbols distinct, the Eight Trigrams complete,
At their intersection,
More delicate and shy,
Heaven and Earth, male and female—
Their entwining reveals deep passion, the jade body softens.

**Refining the Substance:**
Returning to the origin, seek it here,
Circulating through the golden crucible, tiger and dragon roar.
The body does not age,
Worldly defilements cannot invade,
The face reverts to youth, the bones turn to gold.

**Divine Marvel:**
Returning to the initial state, transformed into a youth,
Where the auspicious lotus blooms, its color radiant red.
Within the golden crucible,
Vast and dim,
Exchanging bones, adding sinews—everywhere open.

**Knowing the Path:**
Which immortal scripture describes this method?
The *Cantong Qi* and the *Great Change* reveal yin and yang.
You must master it,
Do not act recklessly,
Those who succeed gain renown, the Dao naturally flourishes.

**Facing the Emperor:**
Nine cycles complete, the count is exhausted,
Open the furnace, lift the crucible—behold the golden elixir.
Feasting done,
Depart the mortal realm,
Tread upon blue clouds, ascend to heaven.

**Aligning with Principle:**
All the world’s people—on what do they rely?
If not seeking within, whom else would you seek?
Cut off desires,
Sever greed and delusion,
Do not deceive the spirit in darkness.

**Free from Care:**
To study the Dao, begin here,
Sever attachment and love, part from delicate softness.
Ever guard stillness,
Dwell in deep seclusion,
Feast on qi, drink the dawn’s glow—sated, then rest.

**What Use?**
Greed for wealth, greed for glory, chasing profit and fame,
Wandering drunk, clinging to fear and passion.
If you do not seek,
The years will startle you,
When this body ends, where will you be born?

**Swift as Lightning:**
Through ten thousand kalpas and a thousand lives, to gain a human form—
You must know the causes planted in past lives.
Hasten to awaken,
Escape the sea of delusion,
Lest you suffer the bitterness of samsara.

**Ever at Ease:**
Close your eyes to seek the true—the true returns of itself,
A single luminous pearl shines brightly.
All day long,
Do not cast it aside,
Lest the King of Hell dispatch messengers to pursue you.

---

**Eleven *Dream of Jiangnan* Songs**

**Huainan’s Method:**
Huainan’s method, Huainan’s method,
Autumn stone is most worthy of praise.
Its position aligns with heaven and earth, adorned with white dew,
Its form shifts in Yin and Mao, bearing the river chariot,
At Zi and Wu, it congeals the morning glow.

**Wang Yang’s Art:**
Wang Yang’s art, Wang Yang’s art,
The secret lies in the yellow sprout.
The first of myriad medicines resembles this,
Tuned to the Yellow Bell, it returns home,
In the tenth month, you may surely boast.

**The Yellow Emperor’s Guard:**
The Yellow Emperor’s guard, the Yellow Emperor’s art,
Mysteriously wondrous, the golden flower.
The jade liquid first congeals, the red powder appears,
Heaven and Earth’s covering and bearing secretly intertwine,
Dragon and tiger transform into cinnabar.

**The Art of Longevity:**
The art of longevity, the art of longevity,
The mysterious essentials mend the mud pill.
Peng Zu attained it, living eight hundred years,
Yet people harm themselves thereby—
Who truly knows the yin elixir?

**The Yin Elixir’s Secret:**
The yin elixir’s secret, the yin elixir’s secret,
The three and five unite in the mysterious diagram.
The two and eight respond to the mechanism, fit for gathering and moving,
The jade and the moon turn back—the hare’s glory withers,
The countenance surpasses that of mortal sisters.

**The Art of Longevity:**
The art of longevity, the art of longevity,
The first nine conceal the hidden dragon.
Beware of ascending too high—best to be a guest,
Qi flows through the cinnabar field, communicating,
The aged revert to infants.

**The Cultivator of the Body:**
Cultivator of the body, cultivator of the body,
Do not err and enter the sea of delusion.
The qi guards the golden elixir, transmitted in the world,
Resembling heaven, resembling earth, resembling the human body—
No need to ask neighbors.

**The Returning Elixir’s Secret:**
The returning elixir’s secret, the returning elixir’s secret,
Nine nines are most profound.
The three sacrificial animals are originally one within the body,
To refine the divine medicine, urgently seek lead—
Finding it, you are an immortal.

**The Elixir of Longevity:**
The elixir of longevity, the elixir of longevity,
No need to ask others.
The Eight Trigrams and Nine Palaces—observe them in your palm,
The Five Phases and Four Symbols reside within the body—
Understanding, you naturally attain the divine.

**The Student of the Dao:**
Student of the Dao, student of the Dao,
Cultivate and nourish—do not delay.
Light and shadow in an instant, like a dream,
A grain of the returning elixir transforms into golden form—
When you die, do not return.

**The Manager of Life:**
Manager of life, manager of life,
Examine closely, heed subtle words.
A hundred years in a dream pass in an instant—
I urge you to refine and preserve your honored years,
Soon you will be an immortal.
