Fu rose and said, "I happen to have a hundred coins—shall we go to the tavern for a drink?" Fu followed him. From then on, the visitor came every few days, sometimes staying for wine, sometimes for a meal. Fu’s eyes were dim and wept often. The guest taught him to take equal parts of fresh and prepared *dihuang* (Rehmannia), slice and dry them, remove the seeds from Sichuan peppercorns (discarding any with closed mouths), lightly toast them, then blend all three with honey to form pills. He instructed Fu to take fifty pills on an empty stomach with salted rice broth. Fu prepared the medicine as directed, and after a month, his vision cleared—he could see by day and night.

After half a year of visits, the guest suddenly took his leave, saying, "In a few days, I will travel to Xiangyang. Could you accompany me west?" Fu declined, citing his heavy burdens. The guest smiled and said, "I knew you would not go." He took up a brush and wrote four characters—*Profit, Luck, Harmony, Union*—and handed them to Fu, saying, "Post these on your shop wall, and your earnings will increase a hundredfold." He then pulled Fu to the tavern to drink in farewell. From his sleeve, he drew a paper packet containing several ink sticks and said, "I intend to take these to Xiangyang as gifts. Let me leave them with you for now; I’ll retrieve them before I depart." After drinking, Fu returned home and placed the ink on the rack.

Two months passed, and the guest did not return. Fu opened the packet to find it was the Lü Dongbin statue—precisely the one woven from bamboo strips that had stood before the shrine. He searched the basket inside the shrine, but it was empty. Only then did he realize the guest had been Lü Dongbin, and he deeply regretted missing the encounter. He posted the four characters on the wall, and his business flourished daily. He lived to eighty-nine, his ears sharp, his eyes bright, and his vigor like that of a youth.

**The Courtesan of Anfeng Cured**
At the end of the Yuanyou era, a courtesan named Sanxiang in Anfeng County fell gravely ill. No treatment cured her, and in her poverty, she took lodgers to support herself. One day, a poor scholar arrived seeking shelter, asking for the best room. The servant, seeing his ragged clothes, refused him, but Sanxiang said, "Why choose between rich and poor?" She welcomed him in. Soon after, the scholar heard her groaning in pain and asked the reason. The servant explained. The scholar said, "I can cure this illness." Overjoyed, Sanxiang urged him to help. The scholar sealed her mouth with chopsticks and chanted, "Turn your heart, turn your heart."

At the time, she did not understand. Outside the door stood a large, long-dead *zaojia* tree. The scholar placed a pill into a crevice in the tree, sealing it with mud. Suddenly, he vanished. That night, the tree sprouted branches and leaves, growing lush by the day. Sanxiang’s illness was instantly cured. Only then did she realize "turn your heart" (*hui xin*) referred to Lü (Dongbin). She abandoned her home to seek her master. The townspeople built a shrine to the Perfected One at the site.

In the fourteenth year of the Shaoxing era, Sanxiang suddenly returned to her hometown, her appearance youthful and radiant. Elders who recognized her told the prefectural governor, Wu Yi Daifu Zize, who summoned her for questioning. She refused to speak in detail, and later, her whereabouts became unknown.

**Selling Medicine in Yueyang**
Lü Dongbin traveled to Yueyang, where he disguised himself and sold medicine, pricing each pill at a thousand gold pieces. After three days with no buyers, he ascended Yueyang Tower, consumed one of his own pills, and suddenly rose into the air. The crowd, astonished and envious, clamored to buy his medicine. Dongbin laughed and said, "The Dao is before your eyes, yet you tread the paths of Penglai in vain. You grasp the trigger but do not fire—missing it even when face-to-face." He then recited a poem:

*At dawn I roam the northern Yue, by dusk the southern Wu,*
*My sleeve holds the green serpent, my gall bold as a tiger’s.*
*Thrice I entered Yueyang, yet none knew me—*
*Reciting verses, I soared over Dongting Lake.*

**Offering the Elixir in Chengdu**
At the medicine market in Chengdu, a Daoist with a grimy face and tattered robes held up a single elixir, shouting to the crowd, "I am Lü Dongbin! Whoever bows to me twice may have this pill." The people thought him mad and followed, laughing. The Daoist walked back and forth several times, but no one bowed. He then sat by the large pond in front of the Wuxian Temple. Children pelted him with tiles and stones, but he only smiled and said, "The world longs to see me, yet when they do, they do not recognize me. Such is fate."

Lü then consumed the golden elixir himself. Soon, five-colored clouds enveloped him, and he vanished. The crowd was filled with regret.

**The Silk-Wrapped Medicine**
During a year of rampant malaria in the Eastern Capital, an old woman who ran a vegetarian teahouse saw her children and grandchildren all fall ill. One day, a Daoist arrived. The woman treated him kindly and begged him to cure her family. The Daoist said, "Wait for me tomorrow morning."

The next day, the woman rose early to await him. The Daoist took out a medicine wrapped in fine silk and said, "When the illness strikes, have the afflicted hold this—all will be cured. One pill can heal a hundred people, but beyond that, it will lose its efficacy." The woman followed his instructions, and her family recovered. She then treated a hundred others, but once the number was exceeded, the medicine no longer worked.

She opened the silk pouch to find the medicine gone—only three characters remained: *Lü Dongbin*. Only then did she realize she had encountered Master Lü.

**Saving a Mother in Xiao Gan**

Afterward, the Daoist raised his cup, drew the character *Lü* in water, and said, “We shall meet again in Jiangnan next year.” The following year, Huang was indeed transferred to an official post in Jiangnan, where he once more encountered Lü Dongbin. In the depths of winter, Li encountered a destitute Daoist, clad in but a single layer of clothing yet showing no sign of cold. The Daoist followed Li into a wineshop and seated himself at the host’s place, which Li found strange. The shopkeeper said, “Pay for the wine first.” The Daoist pointed to three wine jars in the shop and said, “Each contains a pint’s worth of wine money.” The shopkeeper checked and found it to be true, then gave them three pints of wine. The Daoist poured and drank, while Li took only one jar for himself—the other two emptied on their own. The Daoist said to Li, “This is but a minor art. I am Lü Dongbin.” Startled and overjoyed, Li heard the Daoist inscribe a quatrain:

Ninefold heavens’ Son gathers the favored few,

chunks.original_text: 绍兴二十年，茅山大修醮事。 江束运使郑清，卿王亦颜同往纵观。 至午，憩於茅舍。 遇道人，白苎衫，青布巾，修眉美髯，风骨清俊。 郑王相谓曰：岂非吕仙翁乎。 召与语，命之坐，酌酒数行，两主人皆已醉。 馒问客曰：能更进否。 曰：能。 可饮几何，曰：无筹。 乃令侍史注酒两壶於银盆中，恣其痛饮一杯，复一杯不已。 郑曰：先生如有药，求数粒。 曰：有。 即引手擦左腋下垢汗，捻成青粒与之，曰：只可嗅，不得吃。 王亦求之，复擦右腋下污，成红粒与之，所言亦然。 酒尽，客去。 先是一老兵守邸阁，一漕老兵卧檐问，日晏未醒，漕因戏以两药纳其鼻中，气即吸入，犹未觉。 使人唤之起，问曰：汝觉四体如何。 曰：觉得极轻，殆欲凌云耳。 明日，腾空而去。 二漕相视，悔恨无绿。 盖假手以度老兵也。 何仙遇道 何仙姑，零陵市道女也。 始十三岁，随女伴入山采茶，俄失伴，独行迷归。 路见束峰下一人，修髯、钳目、冠高冠、衣六铢衣，即洞宾也。 仙姑始仆仆亟拜之，洞宾出一桃曰：汝年幼必好果物，食此尽，他日当飞升，不然止居地中也。 仙姑仅能食其半，髯者指以归路。 仙姑归自谓：止一日。 不知已逾月矣。 自是不饥无漏洞，知人事休咎。 后尸解去。 洞宾尝谓仙姑曰：吾尝游华阴市中卖药，以灵丹一粒置他药万粒中，有求药者，於瓢中信手探取与之，观其绿分也。 如是数日，他药五万粒探取八丁，而此丹入手即坠。 因叹世问仙骨难值如此。 跛仙遇道 长沙刘跛仙，遇洞宾於君山，得灵龟吞吐之法。 功成归隐岳麓，自号潇湘子。 常侍洞宾往来抱黄洞，宾数游城下，有诗曰：南山七十二，独爱洞真墟。 后有郑思者，遇跛仙于清泰门外，相与俱仙云。 道友讲经 陈澹然，富而儒者也。 性慕道，延云水士多年，竟无所遇。 洞宾诡为佣者，为治圃岁余，所作工役力过常人。 陈爱之，然止以佣者待之而已。 一日陈与一道友讲《 阴符经》 ，至天发杀机、天地返覆，未晓杀机之旨。 洞宾从旁抗声曰：生者不生，死者不死，已生而杀生，未无而学死，则长生矣。 陈大骂曰：汝非佣者邪，谁教汝为此言。 既而请之，则复缪愆其辞，不可解。 道友曰：田野村夫，定於何处窃得此语耳，非实通晓也。 居无何，忽辞陈曰：吾将远行，明年五月五日午时复来也。 既去寂然，陈有乡人客于巴陵，遇之曰：为我寄语陈公，我吕洞宾也。 始意公可授道，徐察之则不然，吾不复来矣。 言讫，走入吕仙亭竹林中不见。 明年端午日午时，陈公暴卒。 吕祖志卷之三竟 吕祖志卷四

In the twentieth year of the Shaoxing reign, Maoshan conducted a grand Daoist jiao ritual. Zheng Qing, the Transport Commissioner of Jiangdong, and Wang Yiyan, a minister, went together to observe. By midday, they rested at a thatched cottage. There they met a Daoist, clad in a white ramie robe and a black cloth headscarf, with long eyebrows and a fine beard, his bearing refined and elegant. Zheng and Wang remarked to each other, "Could this be the Immortal Lü?" They summoned him for conversation, invited him to sit, and poured several rounds of wine, by which time both hosts were already drunk. The Daoist asked his guest, "Can you drink more?" The guest replied, "I can." "How much can you take?" "Without measure." Thereupon, he ordered his attendant to pour two pots of wine into a silver basin, letting the guest drink to his heart's content—one cup after another without cease. Zheng said, "Master, if you have any elixir, I would beg a few grains." The Daoist replied, "I do." He then reached out, scraped the grime from beneath his left armpit, rolled it into green pellets, and gave them to Zheng, saying, "You may only inhale them, not swallow." Wang also asked for some, so the Daoist scraped the dirt from beneath his right armpit, formed red pellets, and gave them to him with the same instruction. When the wine was finished, the guest departed.

Earlier, an old soldier had been guarding the lodging hall, while another old transport soldier lay sleeping under the eaves, not waking even as the day grew late. In jest, the transport soldier placed the two pellets into the old soldier’s nostrils. The qi was immediately drawn in, yet the old soldier remained unaware. Someone roused him and asked, "How do your limbs feel?" He replied, "I feel extremely light, as if I could ascend to the clouds." The next day, he rose into the air and departed. The two transport officials looked at each other in regret, realizing they had missed their chance. This was but a borrowed hand to deliver the old soldier.

**Encounter with the Dao: He the Immortal Maiden**
He Xiangu was a Daoist maiden from the market of Lingling. At thirteen, she followed her female companions into the mountains to pick tea. Suddenly, she lost her companions and wandered alone, unable to find her way home. On the path, she saw a man beneath an eastern peak—tall, with a long beard, piercing eyes, a lofty cap, and a robe of six layers: it was Lü Dongbin. The maiden prostrated herself repeatedly in haste and bowed to him. Dongbin produced a peach and said, "You are young and must love fruit. Eat this entirely, and one day you will ascend in flight. If not, you will remain earthbound." The maiden could only eat half. The bearded man pointed out her way home. When she returned, she thought only a day had passed, but in truth, a month had elapsed. From then on, she neither hungered nor suffered from bodily leaks, and she could foresee the fortunes and misfortunes of others. Later, she departed through *shijie* (corpse liberation).

Dongbin once said to the maiden, "I once wandered the market of Huayin selling medicine. I placed a single grain of spiritual elixir among ten thousand grains of other remedies. When someone sought medicine, I would casually scoop some from the gourd and give it to them, observing their karmic affinity. Over several days, eighty thousand grains of the other medicines were taken, yet this elixir would fall from the hand the moment it was grasped. Alas, how rare it is to encounter one with the bone structure of an immortal in this world!"

**Encounter with the Dao: Liu the Lame Immortal**
Liu the Lame Immortal of Changsha met Dongbin on Junshan and received the method of the灵龟吞吐 (Spiritual Tortoise’s Inhalation and Exhalation). After mastering the practice, he retired to Mount Yuelu and styled himself Master of the Xiao and Xiang Rivers. He often accompanied Dongbin to and from Baohuang Cave. Dongbin frequently wandered beneath the city walls and wrote a poem:
*"Of the seventy-two peaks of the Southern Mountains,
I love only the cave of true emptiness."*
Later, a man named Zheng Si encountered the Lame Immortal outside the Qingtai Gate, and together they ascended as immortals.

**Daoist Friends Discussing Scriptures**
Chen Danran was a wealthy scholar who admired the Dao. For many years, he invited wandering Daoists to stay, yet he never encountered a true master. Dongbin disguised himself as a laborer and worked in Chen’s garden for over a year, performing tasks with strength beyond that of ordinary men. Chen grew fond of him but treated him as nothing more than a hired hand. One day, Chen and a Daoist friend were discussing the *Yinfu Jing* (Scripture of Hidden Agreement). When they reached the passage, *"Heaven unleashes its killing mechanism; heaven and earth are overturned,"* they could not fathom the meaning of the "killing mechanism." Dongbin, standing nearby, spoke up loudly: *"That which is born does not live; that which dies does not perish. To kill the living after it is born, or to learn death before it is absent—this is the way to long life."* Chen rebuked him angrily: "Are you not a laborer? Who taught you to speak thus?" When pressed further, Dongbin deliberately garbled his words, making them incomprehensible. The Daoist friend said, "This rustic must have overheard such talk somewhere. He does not truly understand it."

Soon after, Dongbin suddenly took leave of Chen, saying, "I will travel far. I shall return on the fifth day of the fifth month next year at noon." After his departure, all was quiet. Later, one of Chen’s fellow townsmen was visiting Baling and encountered Dongbin, who said, "Tell Master Chen for me: I am Lü Dongbin. At first, I thought he might be worthy of receiving the Dao, but upon closer observation, I saw otherwise. I shall not return." With that, he walked into the bamboo grove of the Lüxian Pavilion and vanished. On the noon of the fifth day of the fifth month the following year, Master Chen suddenly died.

*Record of the Patriarch Lü, Scroll Three—concluded*

**Record of Arts and Literature**

**Five Ancient Poems in *Gufeng* Style**

**First Poem: A Record**

For years I delighted in seclusion’s quiet,
Seeking escape from cold and heat’s oppression.
I sought no fame nor profit,
Yet still feared the toil of body and mind.
With earnest resolve, I yearned for the *Yellow Court*,
Diligently pursuing the traces of the Dao.
In secret, I cultivated hidden virtue,
Accumulating good deeds day by day.
At last, upon the worldly path, I met my master—
A man unrecognized by all.
My master’s movements were subtle, his conduct discreet,
His bearing solitary, his nature aloof.
He could shift the Five Phases,
And alter the Four Symbols.
He transmitted to me the Gate of Creation,
Where I first grasped the principle of *Xiyi*.
Ingesting the twofold truth,
I followed the path to its very source.
Boiling the sun and moon in the crucible,
Never straying from the side of Heaven and Earth.
The supreme Dao lies before the eyes,
Attained in an instant, yet ever near.
True emptiness is not empty,
True form is not form.
Overturning the jade gourd,
Forth flows the golden elixir.
Grasping the Red Dragon’s head,
I fiercely draw in the Black Pearl.
Swallowing it into my viscera,
I seize the power of immortals.
A single grain of millet,
Extends life by millions of years.
Fellow travelers, heed my song,
And draw closer to the Dao.
Without understanding the true Yellow Sprout,
You wander the purple paths in vain.
Seize the Red Crow’s soul,
And burst forth the Silver Toad’s essence.
If you fail to fathom this mystery,
You will forever drift in shallow streams.
The Three Heavens have their paths,
The Nine Earths know no peril.
Guard the Dao and feign foolishness,
Forget scheming and blend with the dust.
Let none among the multitudes despise you—
You are already a guest of Penglai.

**Two Ancient Poems in *Gufeng* Style**

**Presented to the Recluse Liu Fang**

Grieving the rise and fall of six warring states,
I take my zither and chant, leaving the sacred land.
I would boil white stones in mist and clouds,
But chance upon a city where I meet a man of the Dao.
I have found the Golden Flower’s world-transcending guard,
And hope to ride the clouds to the Purple Palace.
In recent years, I plucked the green jade of Yellow Cliff,
Where jade trees stand tall, rooted in the earth’s lungs.
Dew scatters fragrance over jasper fields, nourishing the sprouts,
The moon rises over emerald peaks, and cranes cry from their boats.
The messages of grotto-heavens run deep in spring,
The immortal’s path is trodden, but mortals cannot follow.
Then, on a whim, I descended from the white clouds,
And chanced upon you in this dusty world.
In this dusty world, our meeting was rare—
We spoke of ancient times and shared the same aspirations.
We played jade zithers and precious lutes,
And drank nectar and jade wine until I grew drunk.
In my drunkenness, I spoke of the rise and fall of nations,
Of how the Dao of clouds knows no worldly burdens.
This fleeting life is but a fleeting dream,
Like a spark or lightning—gone in an instant.
Youth and beauty are not eternal,
Fair faces and jade complexions return to dust.
The fragrant cup is refilled from dawn to dusk,
Joy knows no end, past or present.
How much better to recognize the profound Dao,
Which lies in the unfathomable—ponder it deeply.
Within the crucible, a single grain transforms into a wondrous thing,
Beyond all things, a thousand years of effort hold boundless mystery.
If only you can master the flower in the midst of water,
Water and fire will reverse to form the golden elixir-tortoise.
Once the elixir is complete, you will not linger long among men,
For the celestial decree of the azure skies awaits.
The sunlit valleys of the Mystic Continent are yours to dwell in,
Where earthly longevity and heavenly years are eternally preserved.
Phoenix carriages and crane-drawn chariots soar through the clouds,
The distant Jasper Pool is easily reached.
I hear of wars and collapses,
I see beauty wither into decay.
The old lands of the Tang lie in ruins,
The tombs of the Han are overgrown with white grass.
This world of clashing shells is truly sorrowful—
Cherish your life, do not delay.
Pearls and jades filling your house bring no blessing,
Silks and satins overflowing your chests invite only peril.
The wise have long warned against greed,
The enlightened forget desire—why wait?
Liu Fang, Liu Fang, heed my words:
Time flies swift as a passing shadow.
Sever the roots of yin’s entanglements with resolve,
For the corpse-ghost’s procrastination will be your undoing.
You already know the Eight Jade Secrets—
Do not wait until the cart is broken and the axle snapped.
A broken cart and snapped axle demand alarm—
Even meeting Boyang would be too late.
Worrying endlessly for home and country,
You exhaust the primordial fire of the Three Fields.
The Gate of Mystery lies within reach—
Unlock the golden lock yourself.

**Presented to Qiao Erlang**

Since we met in the imperial capital,
We have been drunk year after year.
In our drunkenness, we often cherished the truth,
Caring little for fame or profit.
I urge you to abandon fleeting glory,
And hasten toward the misty paths of the Dao.
But how to embark on this misty journey?
First, you must make the golden essence fly from behind your elbow.
When the golden essence flies to the Upper Palace,
The Upper and Lower Palaces will be filled with light.
Then, the jade drops will trickle to a halt,
Rushing back to the primordial sea like thunder.
Even if husband and wife meet again,
Their joy will be boundless, their love without end.
Water and fire will be balanced,
And the hanging moment will reverse into Heaven and Earth in harmony.
As yang refines yin through rising and sinking,
Only when yin is exhausted will you grasp this profound truth.
What, after all, is the root and origin?
Clearly, it is but gold within water.
Qiao, Qiao, act swiftly—
Do not chase the flying crow or the running hare.
How much better to cultivate and become a true immortal,
For this floating life in the dusty world will not last.
The great Dao of long life is not easily attained—
From ancient times to now, it has always been so.

**Four Quatrains in Five-Character Style**

**Presented to Li Xiyu of Qizhou**

Drink less wine that deceives the heart,
And never covet unjust wealth.
Blessings come from kindness,
Disaster strikes the cunning and deceitful.

**Inscribed at the Purple Ultimate Palace**

Entering the palace gate in leisure,
I lean on the railing by the water.
No one knows I have come—
Only the red-crested crane cries urgently.

**Presented to the Recluse Shen Zhenji (Two Poems)**

On the crane’s back, I sing a long song,
Its clear notes echoing through the forest.
A thousand miles away, Dongting’s autumn—
Lake waves play with the bright moon.

The moon has already turned pale,
My poem complete as dawn approaches.
Suddenly, the lone crane vanishes,
And idle clouds drift away.

**Eighteen Regulated Verses in Five-Character Style**

Having awakened to the principle of long life,
Autumn lotuses bloom everywhere.
The Golden Lad ascends the brocade canopy,
The Jade Maiden descends the fragrant steps.
When the tiger roars, the celestial soul abides,
When the dragon chants, the earthly spirit comes.
Whoever understands this Dao
Instantly returns to infancy.

The Alchemical Maiden dwells in the south,
Beside her, the Great Sun is born.
In the Toad Palace, jade liquid is boiled,
At the Kan Gate, jade nectar is refined.
The immortals of the past consumed it—
Now it is my turn to taste.

chunks.original_text: 一杯延万纪，物外任翱翔。 顿悟黄芽理，阴阳禀自然。 乾坤炉裹炼，日月鼎中煎。 木产长生汞，金生续命铅。 世人明此道，立便返童颜。 宇宙产黄芽，经炉缎作砂。 阴阳烹五彩，水火炼三花。 鼎内龙降虎，壶中龟遣蛇。 功成归物外，自在乐烟霞。 要觅长生路，除非认本源。 都来一味药，刚到数千般。 丹鼎烹成汞，红炉炼作铅。 依时服一粒，白日上冲天。 姹女住瑶台，仙花满地开。 金苗从此出，玉药自天来。 凤舞长生曲，鸾歌续命杯。 有人明此道，海变已千回。 古往诸仙子，根元占甲庚。 水中闻虎啸，火裹见龙行。 进退穷三候，相吞用八弦。 冲天功行满，寒暑不能争。 我悟长生理，太阳伏太阴。 离宫生白玉，坎户产黄金。 要主君臣义，须存子母心。 九重神室内，虎啸与龙吟。 灵丹产太虚，九转入重炉。 浴就红莲颗，烧成白玉珠。 水中铅一两，火内汞三铢。 吃了瑶台宝，升天任每枯。 姥女住离宫，身边产雌雄。 炉中七返毕，鼎内九还终。 悟了鱼投水，迷因乌在笼。 耄年服一粒，立地变冲童。 道德乾坤祖，阴阳是本宗。 天魂生白虎，地魄产青龙。 运宝泥丸住。 搬精入上宫。 有人明此法，万载貌如童。 要觅金丹理，根元不易逢。 三才七返足，四象九还终。 浴就微微白，烧成渐渐红。 一丸延万纪，物外去冲冲。 个个觅长生，根元不易寻。 要贪天上宝，须弃世问琛，炼就水中火，烧成阳内阴。 祖师亲有语，一味水中金。 万物皆生玉，如人得本元。 青龙精是汞，白虎水为铋。 悟者子投母，迷应地是天。 将来物外客，个个补丹田。 二十四神清，三于功行成。 寒云连地转，圣日满天明。 玉子偏宜种，金田岂在耕。 此中真妙理，谁道不长生。 钞钞纱中纱，玄玄玄更玄。 动言俱演道，语默尽神仙。 在掌如珠异，当空似月圆。 他时功满后，直入大罗天。 密室静存神，阴阳重一斤。 炼成离女液，咽尽坎男津。 渐变逍遥体，超然自在身。 更修功业满，旌鹤引朝真。 通道复通玄，名留四海传。 交亲一柱杖，和气两空拳。 要果遗巡种，思荼逐旋煎。 岂知来混世，不久却回天。 七言绝句四十二首 捉得金精固命基，日魂束畔月华西。 於中炼就长生药，服了还同天地齐。 莫怪瑶池消息稀，只绿人事隔天机。 若人寻得水中火，有一黄童上太微。 混元海底隐生伦，内有黄童玉帝名。 白虎神符潜姥女，灵元镇在七元君。 三亩丹田无种种，种时须借赤龙耕。 曾将此种教人种，不解沿池道不生。 闪灼虎龙神剑飞，好凭身事莫相违。 传时须在乾坤力，便透三清入紫微。 不用梯媒向外求，还丹只在体中收。 莫言大道人难得，自是功夫不到头。 饮酒须教一百杯，束浮西泛自梯如。 日精能与月华合，有个明珠走上来。 不负二光不负人，不欺神道不欺贫。 有人问我修行法，只种心田养自身。 时人若拟去瀛洲，先过巍巍十八楼。 自是电雷声震动，一池金水向束流。 瓶子如金玉子黄，上升下降续神光。 三元一会经年争，这个天中日月长。 学道须教彻骨贫，囊中只有五三文。 有人问我修行法，遥指天边日月轮。 我自忘心神自悦，跨水穿云来相谒。 不问黄芽肘后方，纱道通微怎生说。 丹传肘后千年术，口诵黄庭两卷经。 鹤观古坛松影裹，悄无人迹户长肩。
chunks.translated_text:
A cup extends ten thousand ages,
Beyond the world, one soars at will.
Sudden awakening to the principle of the Yellow Sprout—
Yin and yang bestowed by nature.
Within the Qian-Kun furnace, refinement,
In the sun-moon cauldron, decoction.
Wood yields the mercury of long life,
Metal births the lead of continued fate.
Whoever understands this Dao
Instantly regains a youthful face.

The cosmos births the Yellow Sprout,
Through the furnace, wrought into cinnabar.
Yin and yang refine the five hues,
Water and fire temper the Three Flowers.
Within the cauldron, the dragon descends, the tiger arrives,
In the pot, the tortoise dispatches the snake.
The work complete, one returns beyond the world,
Freely delighting in mist and rosy clouds.

To seek the path of long life,
One must recognize the root source.
Though it is but a single medicine,
Its forms number in the thousands.
In the elixir tripod, mercury is refined,
In the red furnace, lead is smelted.
Take one pill at the proper time,
And ascend to heaven in broad daylight.

The Alchemical Maiden dwells in the Jade Terrace,
Immortal blossoms carpet the ground.
The golden sprout emerges here,
The jade elixir descends from heaven.
The phoenix dances the melody of long life,
The simurgh sings the cup of continued fate.
Whoever understands this Dao
Has witnessed the sea transform a thousand times.

The immortals of ancient times
Rooted their origin in jia and geng.
In water, the tiger’s roar is heard,
In fire, the dragon’s movement seen.
Advancing and retreating through the three watches,
Devouring one another with the eight trigrams.
When the work of ascending heaven is complete,
Neither cold nor heat can contend.

I have awakened to the principle of long life—
The Great Yang subdues the Great Yin.
The Li Palace births white jade,
The Kan Gate yields yellow gold.
To uphold the righteousness of lord and minister,
One must preserve the heart of mother and child.
Within the ninefold divine chamber,
The tiger roars and the dragon chants.
The numinous elixir emerges from the Great Void,
Ninefold refined, it enters the layered furnace.
Bathed, it becomes a crimson lotus seed,
Burnished, a white jade pearl.
An ounce of lead in water,
Three grains of mercury in fire.
Consume the treasure of the Jade Terrace,
And ascend to heaven at will, ever verdant.

The Crone dwells in the Li Palace,
Beside her, the feminine and masculine arise.
In the furnace, the sevenfold return is complete,
In the tripod, the ninefold restoration ends.
Awakened, the fish leaps into water,
Deluded, the crow remains in the cage.
At advanced age, take one pill,
And instantly transform into a soaring youth.

Dao and virtue are the ancestors of heaven and earth,
Yin and yang their root lineage.
The celestial soul births the White Tiger,
The earthly spirit yields the Azure Dragon.
Convey the treasure to lodge in the Mud Pill,
Transfer the essence into the Upper Palace.
Whoever understands this method
Will retain a youthful countenance for ten thousand years.

To seek the principle of the Golden Elixir,
The root origin is not easily found.
The Three Powers fulfill the sevenfold return,
The Four Images complete the ninefold restoration.
Bathed, it becomes faintly white,
Burnished, gradually red.
One pill extends ten thousand ages,
Beyond the world, one ascends in boundless flight.

Each seeks long life,
Yet the root origin is not easily found.
To covet the treasure of heaven,
One must forsake worldly riches.
Refine the fire within water,
Burn the yin within yang.
The Patriarch’s own words:
A single taste of gold within water.
All things are born of jade,
As humans attain their root origin.
The essence of the Azure Dragon is mercury,
The White Tiger’s water is lead.
The awakened child returns to the mother,
The deluded mistake earth for heaven.
Those who come as guests beyond the world
Each replenish their cinnabar field.
The twenty-four spirits purified,
The three thousand merits accomplished.
Cold clouds stretch across the earth,
The sacred sun fills the sky.
The Jade Lad is fit for planting,
The Golden Field need not be tilled.
Within this true and wondrous principle,
Who says one cannot attain long life?

Layer upon layer of gauze,
Mystery upon mystery, ever more profound.
In movement, speech expounds the Dao,
In stillness, silence embodies immortality.
In the palm, it shines like a pearl,
In the sky, it hangs like a full moon.
When the work is complete in time,
One enters the Great Luo Heaven directly.

In the secluded chamber, silently preserve the spirit,
Yin and yang weigh as one.
Refine the liquid of the Maiden of Li,
Swallow the essence of the Youth of Kan.
Gradually transform into a carefree body,
Transcend into a self-sufficient being.
With further cultivation, merits complete,
The crane’s banner heralds the audience with the Perfected.

The Dao penetrates, the mysterious penetrates further,
A name left to spread across the four seas.
To kin, a single staff,
To harmony, two empty fists.
To bear fruit, plant the seeds without delay,
To refine bitterness, heat it without pause.
Little did they know, coming to blend with the world,
Soon they would return to heaven.

**Forty-Two Quatrains in Seven-Character Style**

Seizing the golden essence to secure life’s foundation,
The sun’s soul to the east, the moon’s radiance to the west.
Within, the elixir of long life is refined—
Consumed, one equals heaven and earth.

No wonder the Jade Pool’s news is scarce,
For human affairs veil celestial mechanisms.
If one finds the fire within water,
A Yellow Lad ascends to the Grand Tenuity.

In the primordial sea’s depths, hidden are the ranks of life,
Within, the Yellow Lad bears the Jade Emperor’s name.
The White Tiger’s divine talisman conceals the Crone,
The numinous origin resides in the Seven Primes.

Three acres of cinnabar field, no seeds to sow,
When planting, one must borrow the Crimson Dragon’s plow.
I once taught others to plant this seed,
Those who fail to follow the pool’s path will not thrive.

The tiger and dragon’s flashing divine swords fly,
Rely on bodily discipline, do not transgress.
Transmission requires the power of heaven and earth,
Then one pierces the Three Clarities to enter the Purple Tenuity.

No need for ladders or matchmakers to seek without,
The returned elixir is gathered within the body.
Do not say the Great Dao is hard for people to attain—
It is only that the work has not reached its culmination.

Drink wine, let it be a hundred cups,
Eastward floating, westward drifting, naturally ascending.
The sun’s essence can unite with the moon’s radiance,
And a bright pearl rises forth.

Unburdened by the two luminaries, unburdened by others,
Neither deceiving the divine way nor the impoverished.
If one asks me of the method of cultivation,
Only plant the heart-field and nurture oneself.

If mortals aspire to reach Penglai,
First cross the towering eighteen peaks.
As thunder’s roar shakes the earth,
A pool of golden water flows eastward.

The vessel like gold, the Jade Lad yellow,
Ascending and descending, extending divine light.
The Three Primes converge over years of strife,
This heaven’s sun and moon endure long.

To learn the Dao, one must be utterly destitute,
With only a few coins in one’s purse.
If one asks me of the method of cultivation,
I point afar to the sun and moon on the horizon.

I forget my heart, my spirit delights,
Striding over water, piercing clouds to visit.
Not inquiring of the Yellow Sprout’s elixir behind the elbow,
How can one speak of the subtle path through gauze?

The elixir transmitted behind the elbow, an art of a thousand years,
Reciting the two scrolls of the *Yellow Court*.
In the crane’s abode, the ancient altar amid pine shadows,
Silent, no footprints, the door forever ajar.

The Golden Lad ascends the brocade canopy,
The Jade Maiden descends the fragrant steps.
When the tiger roars, the celestial soul abides,
When the dragon chants, the earthly spirit comes.
Whoever understands this Dao
Instantly returns to infancy.

The Alchemical Maiden dwells in the south,
Beside her, the Great Sun is born.
In the Toad Palace, jade liquid is boiled,
At the Kan Gate, jade nectar is refined.
The immortals of the past consumed it—
Now it is my turn to taste.

chunks.original_text: 独上高峰望八都，黑云散后月还孤。 茫茫宇宙人无数，几个男儿是丈夫。 天下都游半日功，不须跨凤与乘龙。 偶因博戏飞神剑，摧却终南第一峰。 耀倒葫芦棹却琴，倒行直上外牛岑。 水飞石上迸如雪，立地看天坐地吟。 吾家本住在天齐，零落白云铄石梯。 来往八千消半日，依前归路不曾迷。 黄峰道士高且洁，不下莲官经岁月。 星辰夜礼玉簪寒，龙虎晓开金鼎热。 束山束畔忽相逢，握手丁宁语似锺。 剑术已成君把去，有蛟龙处斩蛟龙。 朝泛苍梧暮却还，洞中日月我为天。 匣藏宝剑时时吼，不遇同人誓不传。 猥仙拍手葫芦舞，过岭穿云拄杖飞。 来往八千须半日，金州南畔有松扉。 养得兄形似我形，我身枯梓子光精。 生生世世常如此，争似留神养自身。 精养灵根气养神，此真之外更无真。 神仙不肯分明说，迷了千千万万人。 不事王侯不种田，日高犹自抱琴眠。 起来旋点黄金买，不使人问作业钱。 天涯海角人求我，行到天涯不见人。 忠孝义慈行方便，不须求我自成真。 莫道幽人一事无，闲中尽有静工夫。 闭门清昼读书罢，扫地焚香到日哺。 息精息气养精神，精养丹田气养身。 有人学得这般术，便是长生不死人。 斗笠为帆扇作舟，五湖四海任遨游。 大千世界须臾至，石烂松枯经几秋。 或为道士或为僧，混俗和光别有能。 苦海翻成天上路，昆卢常点百千灯。 过洞庭湖君山 午夜君山骯月回，西邻小圃碧莲开。 天香风露苍华玲，蕾在青霄鹤未来。 赠凤翔府天庆观 得道年来八百秋，不曾飞剑取人头。 玉皇未有天符至，且货乌金混世流。 剑画於襄阳雪中 岘山一夜玉龙寒，凤林千树梨花老。 襄阳城裹少人知，襄阳城外江山好。 海上逢赵同 南宫水火吾须济，北关夫妻我自媒。 洞裹龙儿娇郁律，山前童子喜徘徊。 赠剑客五首 先生先生貌狞恶，拔剑当空气云错。 连喝三回急急去，钦然空裹人头落。 剑起星奔万里珠，风雷时逐雨声麓。 人头携处非人在，何事高吟过五湖。 麓眉卓坚语如雷，闻说不平便放杯。 使剑当空千里去，一更别我一更回。 庞眉国坚恶精神，万里腾空一踊身。 背上匣中三尺剑，为天且示不平人。 先生先生莫外求，道要人传剑要收。 今日相逢江海畔，一杯村酒劝君休。 赠曹先生 鹤不西飞龙不行，露乾云破洞萧清。 少年仙子说闲事，遥隔彩云闻叹声。 与潭州智度寺慧觉禅师有序 余游韶彬，束下湘江。 今见觉公，观其禅学精明，性源纯洁，促膝静坐，收光内照。 一袖之外无余衣，一钵之外无余食。 达生死岸，破烦恼壳。 方今佛衣寂寂兮无传，禅理悬悬兮几绝。 扶而兴者，其在吾师乎。 达者惟心兼济物，圣贤传法不离真。 请师开说西来意，七祖如今未有人。 闲题一首 独自行来独自坐，无限世人不识我。 惟有城南老树精，分明知我神仙过。 松枯石老水萦回，个裹难教俗客来。 台眼试看山外景，纷纷风急障黄埃。 七言律诗六十首 夹脊双关透顶门，修行径路此为根。 华池神水频来咽，紫府元君往济浔。 常使气冲关节透，自然精满谷神伸。 他年得赴瑶池会，须感当初指教人。 调气诀。 混混沌沌不计年，一吸略记五千言。 烧丹炼药南山秀，服气吞霞九海乾。 曾经几度须眉滥，数番沧海变桑田。 陛下问臣年多少，先有吾身后有天。
chunks.translated_text:
Alone I ascend the high peak to gaze upon the Eight Capitals,
Black clouds disperse, the moon remains solitary.
Boundless the cosmos, numberless its people—
How many men among them are true husbands?

Roaming all under heaven takes but half a day’s work,
No need to ride phoenix or mount dragon.
By chance in a game of chance, my spirit-sword takes flight,
Shattering the first peak of Mount Zhongnan.

I overturn the gourd, strike aside the zither,
Walking backward, I ascend beyond Oxherd Summit.
Water flies from stone, bursting like snow,
Standing I gaze at heaven, sitting I chant.

My home was originally at Heaven’s Pivot,
Scattered like drifting white clouds, melting the stone steps.
Coming and going eight thousand leagues consumes half a day,
Yet the old return path remains unlost.

The Daoist of Yellow Peak is lofty and pure,
He does not descend from the Lotus Palace for years.
By night he bows to stars, his jade hairpin chilled,
By dawn the dragon and tiger stir, the golden crucible hot.

Suddenly we meet by the eastern mountainside,
Grasping hands, we exhort each other, voices ringing like bells.
“Your swordcraft is complete—take it with you,
Where dragons dwell, there slay dragons.”

At dawn I sail to Cangwu, by dusk I return,
Within the grotto, sun and moon—here I am heaven.
The casketed treasure-sword roars from time to time,
Yet without meeting one of like kind, I vow not to transmit it.

The Feathered Immortal claps hands, the gourd dances,
Crossing ridges, piercing clouds, the staff flies.
Coming and going eight thousand leagues takes but half a day,
By the southern slopes of Jinzhou, pine gates stand.

Cultivating a form like mine, my body withers to a dry catalpa,
While the disciple’s essence gleams.
Life after life, ever thus—
How could it compare to nurturing one’s own spirit?

Nurture the numinous root with essence, the spirit with qi,
Beyond this truth, there is no truth.
The immortals refuse to speak plainly,
Misleading millions upon millions.

I serve no kings, till no fields,
At high noon I still lie abed, lute in arms.
Rising, I casually mint gold,
Lest others ask for alms-money.

From the ends of the earth, people seek me,
Yet walking to the earth’s end, I find no one.
Loyalty, filial piety, righteousness, compassion—practice convenience,
No need to seek me; you will naturally attain perfection.

Those who call recluses idle know nothing—
In stillness, they perfect their work.
Closing the door on a bright day, reading ends,
Sweeping the floor, burning incense until dusk.

Cease essence, cease qi, nurture the spirit,
Refine essence in the cinnabar field, the body with qi.
Whoever masters this art
Becomes an immortal, deathless.

A bamboo hat for a sail, a fan for a boat,
Roam the Five Lakes and Four Seas at will.
In an instant, traverse the great thousand worlds,
Though stones rot and pines wither through countless autumns.

Some become Daoists, some monks,
Blending with the world, their light veiled, yet gifted.
The bitter sea transforms into a celestial path,
Dipamkara ever lights hundreds of thousands of lamps.

**Crossing Dongting Lake at Jun Mountain**
By midnight, the moon returns over Jun Mountain,
In the western neighbor’s small garden, green lotuses bloom.
Heavenly fragrance, wind, dew—azure blossoms crystalline,
The bud lingers in the blue firmament, the crane has not yet come.

**Presented to Tianqing Abbey in Fengxiang Prefecture**
Eight hundred autumns since attaining the Dao,
Never once has my flying sword taken a head.
Until the Jade Emperor’s celestial decree arrives,
I peddle black gold to mingle with the world’s flow.

**Drawing a Sword in the Snow at Xiangyang**
Jian Mountain, one night, the jade dragon grows cold,
In Phoenix Grove, a thousand trees age like pear blossoms.
Within Xiangyang’s walls, few know—
Beyond Xiangyang’s walls, the rivers and mountains are fair.

**Encountering Zhao Tong at Sea**
In the Southern Palace, water and fire—I must aid,
At the Northern Pass, husband and wife—I myself am matchmaker.
Within the grotto, the dragon-child is proud and spirited,
Before the mountain, the lad delights in lingering.

**Five Poems Presented to a Swordsman**
Sir, sir, your visage fierce and grim,
Drawing your sword midair, qi and clouds clash.
Three sharp shouts, swiftly you depart,
With a *clang*, an empty space—where a head once fell.

The sword rises, stars scatter like ten thousand pearls,
Wind and thunder follow, rain roars in the valleys.
Where the head is carried, no man remains—
Why chant loftily as you cross the Five Lakes?

Brows knit, spirit resolute, voice like thunder,
Hearing of injustice, you cast aside your cup.
Wielding your sword midair, a thousand leagues you go,
Departing at the first watch, returning by the second.

Bushy brows, stalwart frame, fierce spirit,
Ten thousand leagues you leap into the void.
On your back, in its sheath, a three-foot sword—
For heaven, you show yourself as one who rights wrongs.

Sir, sir, seek not without,
The Dao must be transmitted, the sword must be sheathed.
Today we meet by rivers and seas—
A cup of village wine, I urge you to cease.

**Presented to Master Cao**
The crane does not fly west, the dragon does not move,
Dew dries, clouds part, the grotto’s flute is clear.
A young immortal speaks of idle matters,
From afar, beyond colored clouds, a sigh is heard.

**To Chan Master Huijue of Zhidu Temple in Tanzhou, with Preface**
I traveled from Shaobin, eastward down the Xiang River.
Now I meet Master Jue—
Observing his Chan study, keen and bright,
His nature’s source pure and unsullied.
Knees drawn close, he sits in stillness, gathering light within.
Beyond his sleeve, no extra robe;
Beyond his bowl, no extra food.
He has reached the shore of life and death,
Shattered the shell of afflictions.
Now the Buddha’s robe lies silent, untransmitted,
Chan’s principle hangs precariously, nearly lost.
Who will uphold and revive it?
Perhaps it rests with my teacher.

The enlightened aid others with their minds,
Sages and worthies transmit the Dharma without departing from truth.
I ask the master to expound the meaning of the Western advent—
Now, who is the seventh patriarch?

**An Idle Inscription**
Walking alone, sitting alone,
Countless people in the world do not know me.
Only the old tree spirit south of the city
Clearly knows I am an immortal passing by.

Pines wither, stones age, waters coil,
Here, vulgar guests are hard to teach.
From the terrace’s vantage, gaze at the scenery beyond—
Hurried winds stir, obscuring yellow dust.

**Sixty Quatrains in Seven-Character Regulated Verse**
The twin passes of the spine pierce the crown gate,
This is the direct path of cultivation, its root.
From the Flowery Pond, divine water frequently swallowed,
The Purple Palace’s original lord aids the crossing.

Constantly let qi surge through joints and passages,
Naturally, essence fills, the Valley Spirit extends.
In years to come, when attending the Jade Pool assembly,
You must remember the one who first taught you.

**The Art of Qi Regulation**
Chaotic and undifferentiated, years uncounted,
One inhalation barely records five thousand words.
Refining the elixir, concocting medicine, Southern Mountain’s beauty,
Absorbing qi, swallowing auroras, the nine seas dry.

How many times have my brows and temples brimmed?
How often have the seas turned to mulberry fields?
If Your Majesty asks my age,
First came my body, then came heaven.
chunks.overlap_context:
the method of cultivation,
I point afar to the sun and moon on the horizon.

I forget my heart, my spirit delights,
Striding over water, piercing clouds to visit.
Not inquiring of the Yellow Sprout’s elixir behind the elbow,
How can one speak of the subtle path through gauze?

The elixir transmitted behind the elbow, an art of a thousand years,
Reciting the two scrolls of the *Yellow Court*.
In the crane’s abode, the ancient altar amid pine shadows,

chunks.translated_text:
**To You, This Composition**

Our ancestral Dao is fundamentally non-action,
In the white-snow gourd, Kan and Li unite.
Often I drink three cups of carefree wine,
Leisurely I play a game of uncontentious chess.

Extracting lead, adding mercury to preserve the true form,
Returning to the root, restoring the foundation of life.
When you grasp these two merging into one,
At last, you ascend the celestial ladder.

**Probing the Mysteries**

Alone I traverse, surpassing all peers,
Silent and dim, enduring since ancient times.
Formless and shapeless, it subtly creates,
With gates and doors within Heaven and Earth.

At the boundary of form and formlessness, who can fathom?
In the midst of emptiness and non-emptiness, the root is self-attained.
This Dao is not obtained from without—
A thousand words, ten thousand phrases are but idle discourse.

A single grain of numinous true cinnabar,
Not placed at the ends of heaven or earth.
Delving into scriptures yields no depth,
Climbing mountains or facing waters reveals nothing.

Its radiance secretly dwells on the peak of the unseen,
Its brilliance resides high in the chaos’ origin.
If the world could but know its abode,
Transcending the mundane to become a sage would be effortless.

**Fallen Among Red Dust for Forty Springs**

Forty years adrift in the red dust,
Non-action, non-affair, trusting in natural truth.
My livelihood rests only in the cauldron of Heaven and Earth,
My sustenance depends solely on the wheel of sun and moon.

Within the qi of the Eight Trigrams lies the supreme treasure,
Within the light of the Five Agents hides the primordial spirit.
Though mulberry fields transform, it remains unchanged,
Forever a transcendent among mortals.

**Alone Amidst the Myriad Forms of Heaven and Earth**

From the beginning, I meticulously cultivate primordial work.
Wielding the Northern Dipper with vast intent,
Inverting the Southern Stars with bold courage.

Ghosts wail and spirits howl as the golden crucible congeals,
Phoenixes soar and dogs transform as the jade furnace empties.
How can the vulgar world seek it in the ordinary?
Without attaining the unseen, it cannot be fathomed.

**Who Would Believe the Flowery Pond’s Path Runs Deepest?**

Neither near nor far, its mystery is hard to find.
Nine years of refinement like red jade,
One day of perfection like purple gold.

Once attained, it forever resists cold and heat,
Consumed, it shields against life and death.
I urge you, cultivators beyond the gate,
Focus your thoughts on this Dao of the heart.

**From the Water Palace, Seek Lead to Merge with Fire-Lead**

Black to red, red to black—profoundly obscure.
Qi generates qi, transforming flesh and skin,
Essence contains essence, unifying life and nature.

When the medicine returns, you become a true Daoist,
When the elixir reverts, you are a sage embryo immortal.
"Exiting spirit, entering samadhi"—empty words,
Wasting effort for ten thousand years in vain.

**Nine Crucibles Refine Nine-Turned Sand**

Precisely dividing the seasons without error.
Spirit, essence, qi, and blood return to the three essentials,
North and south, east and west unite as one family.

Heaven and Earth transform, white snow flies,
Yin and Yang harmonize, golden blossoms bloom.
Ultimately, phoenix music descends from the void,
Riding tigers and dragons amidst purple clouds.

**Observe at Noon and Midnight, My Lord**

A single pulse of the Celestial Ford lies at the spine’s end.
Within the Golden Gate hides the Mysterious Valley Child,
In the Jade Pool sits the Palace of Supreme Harmony.

Apply only the most wondrous three-cycle fire,
To refine the numinous nine-turned elixir.
I directly point to the many seekers of the Dao—
In action or stillness, never stray from Tiger-Dragon Shoal.

**Returning to the Root, Restoring the Origin, Dao-Qi Levels**

Void yet not form, it becomes increasingly distinct.
In water, white snow subtly congeals,
In fire, golden lotuses gradually bloom.

When discussing sacred mercury, it has no form,
When examining true lead, it too has no name.
I now speak for those who cultivate like mothers—
Do not ask about refining gold, but about the utmost essence.

**Arrange the Crucible and Turtle to Refine the Mysterious Root**

Advance and retreat—know the gates of Mao and You.
Lightning encircles clouds, sun and moon fly,
Driving dragons and tigers out of Heaven and Earth.

One pill bestows upon the lord of youth,
Nine turns can burn away the marks of white hair.
This Dao is subtle, few understand it—
In this vast world, with whom can I discuss it?

**Brewing a Cup of Wine, Composing a Poem**

Drunk at dusk, chanting at dawn, I lose track of years.
The Qian horse often roams the nine earths,
The Kun ox at times emerges from the three heavens.

In the White Tortoise Grotto, husband and wife meet,
In the Azure Phoenix Nest, mother and child unite.
Lifting the numinous child to gaze from the mountain,
Layer upon layer, they are golden coins.

**Recognizing East and West, Wood and Fire**

Naturally, the furnace and crucible roar with tiger and dragon.
Simply follow Heaven and Earth to discern the signs,
Then you will know Yin and Yang’s faithful sounds.

Left hand grasps the Southern Stars, plucking crane feathers,
Right hand holds the Northern Pole, splitting the tortoise’s heart.
The immortals personally left this decree—
Why trouble yourself with external seeking?

**The Heavenly Mechanism Runs Deeper Still**

Vain are words of ten thousand kalpas and a thousand gold.

chunks.original_text: 三冬大热玄中火，六月霜寒表外阴。 金为浮来方见性，木因沉后始知心。 五行颠倒堪消息，返本还元在己寻。 虎将龙军气宇雄，佩符持甲去匆匆。 铺排剑戟奔如电，罗列旌旗疾似风。 活捉三尸焚鬼窟，生擒六贼破魔宫。 河清海宴乾坤争，世世安居道德中。 我家勤种我家田，内有灵苗活万年。 花似黄金苞不大，子如白玉颗皆圆。 栽培全赖中宫土，灌溉须凭上谷泉。 直候九年功满日，和根拔入大罗天。 寻常学道说黄芽，万水千山觅转差。 有吵有圆难下种，无根无脚自开花。 九三鼎内烹如酪，六一炉中结似霞。 不日成丹应化骨，飞升遥指玉皇家。 四六关头路垣平，行人到此不须惊。 从教犊驾轰轰转，尽使羊车轧轧呜。 渡海经河稀阻滞，上天入地绝歌倾。 功成直入长生殿，袖出神珠彻夜明。 九六相交道气和，河车昼夜迸金波。 呼时一一关头转，吸处重重脉上摩。 电激离门光海岳，雷轰震户动婆娑。 思量此道真长远。 学者多迷溺爱河。
chunks.translated_text:
Amidst the three winters, scorching heat—fire within the profound,
In the sixth month’s frost, biting cold—Yin beyond the surface.
Gold, when floating, reveals its nature at last,
Wood, once sunken, discloses its heart in time.
The Five Phases inverted hold the subtle signs,
Returning to the root and restoring the origin lie within one’s own seeking.

The tiger generals and dragon armies, majestic in qi and bearing,
Don their talismans and armor, hastening away.
Swords and halberds arrayed, they charge like lightning,
Banners and standards aligned, they rush swift as the wind.
They capture the Three Corpses alive and burn the demon’s lair,
Seize the Six Bandits alive and shatter the palace of delusion.
When rivers run clear and seas are calm, Heaven and Earth vie in harmony,
Generation after generation dwells secure within the Dao and virtue.

I till my own field with diligence,
Within it, the numinous sprout thrives for ten thousand years.
Its blossoms gleam like yellow gold, though their buds stay small,
Its seeds resemble white jade, each round and perfect.
Its cultivation relies wholly on the soil of the Central Palace,
Its irrigation depends entirely on the springs of the Upper Valley.
Wait until the nine years’ work is complete,
Then uproot it whole and ascend to the Great Luo Heaven.

Ordinary seekers of the Dao speak of the Yellow Sprout,
Yet wander ten thousand rivers and a thousand mountains in vain.
Some are jagged, some round—hard to plant,
Rootless and footless, yet they bloom of themselves.
In the Nine-Three Crucible, they simmer like curds,
In the Six-One Furnace, they congeal like rosy clouds.
Soon the elixir forms, transforming the bones,
And one soars aloft, pointing toward the Jade Emperor’s abode.

At the crossroads of the Four and Six, the path lies smooth and level,
Travelers who reach this point need not fear.
Let the ox-cart rumble and turn,
Let the goat-chariot creak and roll.
Crossing seas and fording rivers, few obstacles remain,
Ascending to Heaven or descending to Earth, no peril tilts the way.
Once the work is done, enter the Hall of Eternal Life,
And from one’s sleeve, draw forth the divine pearl, shining through the night.

When Nine and Six unite, the Dao and qi harmonize,
The River Chariot day and night surges with golden waves.
With each exhalation, it turns at every pass,
With each inhalation, it rubs along the pulse points.
Lightning flashes at the Gate of Li, illuminating sea and mountain,
Thunder roars at the Door of Zhen, shaking the dancing realm.
Reflect on this Dao—truly vast and boundless,
Yet many learners drown in the river of desire.

chunks.original_text: 金丹不是小金丹，阴鼎阳炉裹面安。 尽道束山寻汞易，岂知西海觅铅难。 玄珠窟裹行非远，赤水滩头去便端。 语得灵竿真的路，何劳礼月步星坛。 古今机要甚分明，自是众生力量轻。 尽向有中寻有质，谁能无裹见无形。 真铅圣汞徒虚费，玉室金关不解肩。 本色丹瓢推倒后，却吞丸药待延龄。 浮名浮利两何堪，回首归山味转甘。 举世算无心可契，谁人更与道相参。 寸犹未到甘谈尺，一尚难明强说三。 经卷葫芦并拄杖，依前担入旧江南。 本来无坐亦无行，行着之时是妄情。 老氏语中犹未央，瞿昙言下更难明。 灵竿有节通天去，至药无根得地生。 今日与君无吝惜，功成只此是蓬瀛。 解将火种种刀圭，火种刀圭世岂知。 山上长男骑白马，水边少女牧乌龟。 无中出有还丹象，阴裹生阳大道基。 颠倒五行凭匠手，不逢匠手莫施为。 三千余法论修行，第一烧丹路最亲。 须是坎男端的物，取他离女自然珍。 烹成不死砂中汞，结出长生水裹银。 九转九还功若就，定将衰老返长春。 欲种长生不死根，再营阴魄及阳魂。 先教玄女归离户，复遣空王镇坎门。 虎到甲边风浩浩，龙居庚内水温温。 迷途争与轻轻泄，此理须凭达者论。 闭目存神玉户观，时来火候递相传。 云飞海面龙吞汞，风击岩颠虎伏铅。 一旦炼成身内宝，等闲探得道中玄。 刀圭饵了丹书降，跳出尘龙上九天。 千日工夫不暂闲，河车搬载上昆山。 虎拍白汞安炉裹，龙发红铅向鼎问。 仙府记名丹已熟，阴司除籍命应还。 彩云捧足归何处，直入三清谢圣颜。 解匹真阴与正阳，三年功满结成霜。 神龟出入庚辛位，丹凤翱翔甲乙方。 九鼎先辉双瑞气，三元中换五毫光。 尘中若有同机者，共住烟霄不死乡。 修生一路就中难，迷者徒将万卷看。 水火均平方是药，阴阳差互不成丹。 守雌勿失雄方住，在黑无亏白自乾。 认得此般真妙诀，何忧风雨拓衰残。 才吞一粒便安然，十二重楼九曲连。 庚虎循环飧锋雪，甲龙夭娇迸灵泉。 吕二上应三千日，九九中延九万年。 须得有绿方可授，未曾轻泄与人传。 谁知神水玉华池，中有长生性命基。 运用须凭龙与虎，抽添全籍坎兼离。 晨昏点尽黄金粉，顷刻修成玉石脂。 斋戒饵之千日后，等闲轻举上云梯。 九天云静鹤飞轻，衔简翩翩别太清。 身外红尘随意换，炉中白石立时成。 九苞凤向空中舞，五色云从足下生。 回首便归天上去，愿将甘雨救焦氓。 婴儿迤逦降瑶阶，手握玄珠直下来。 半夜紫云披素质，几回赤气掩桃顺。 微微笑处机关转，拂拂行时户牖开。 此是吾家真一子，庸愚谁敢等闲猜。 才得天符下玉都，三千日裹积工夫。 祷祈天地开金鼎，收拾阴阳锁玉壶。 便觉凡躯能变化，深知妙道不虚图。 时来试问尘中叟，这个玄机世有无。 谁识寰中达者人，生平解法水中银。 一条拄杖撑天地，三尺昆吾斩鬼神。 大醉醉来眠月洞，高吟吟去傲红尘。 自从悟裹终身后，赢得蓬壶永劫春。 红炉进讥炼金英，一点灵珠透室明。 摆动乾坤知道力，逃移生死见功程。 逍遥四海留踪迹，归去三清立姓名。 直上五云云路稳，紫鸾朱凤自来迎。 时人若要学长生，先是枢机昼夜行。 恍惚中问专志气，虚无裹面固元精。 龙友虎战三周毕，兔走乌飞九转成。
chunks.translated_text:
The Golden Elixir is no small golden elixir,
Within the yin crucible and yang furnace it rests secure.
All say it’s easy to seek mercury at Mount Shu,
Yet who knows the difficulty of finding lead in the Western Sea?
The journey to the Cavern of the Mystic Pearl is not far,
At the Ford of Red Waters, the path is straight and true.
Once you grasp the true way of the numinous pole,
Why trouble yourself with moon rites or star-altar steps?

The mechanism of past and present is most clear,
Yet it is only that the strength of all beings is slight.
All seek being within being, substance within substance,
Who can perceive formlessness within the formless?
True lead and sacred mercury are but vain expenditures,
The Jade Chamber and Golden Pass remain unopened.
Once the cinnabar gourd of original nature is overturned,
One swallows pills, awaiting the extension of years.

Fleeting fame and fleeting profit—how can they endure?
Turning one’s head toward the mountains, the flavor grows sweet.
In this world, none share a heart that truly accords,
Who else can engage with the Dao in mutual inquiry?
An inch not yet attained, one glibly speaks of a foot,
One not yet understood, one forcibly expounds on three.
Scriptures, gourds, and staffs as before,
Are carried back into old Jiangnan.

Originally there is no sitting, nor is there walking,
To walk or sit is but delusion.
Laozi’s words remain unexhausted,
Yet even more obscure are the sayings of Gautama.
The numinous pole, jointed, ascends to Heaven,
The supreme medicine, rootless, is born of Earth.
Today I withhold nothing from you,
For when the work is done, this alone is Penglai.

To grasp the fire-seed and plant the knife’s measure,
Who in this world knows of fire-seed or knife’s measure?
The eldest son of the mountain rides a white horse,
The maiden by the water herds a black tortoise.
From non-being emerges being—the image of the Returned Elixir,
Within yin, yang is born—the foundation of the Great Dao.
The inversion of the Five Agents depends on the craftsman’s hand,
Without meeting the craftsman’s hand, do not act.

Of the three thousand and more methods of cultivation,
The first and closest path is the firing of the elixir.
It must be the true substance of the Kan male,
To take the Li female is naturally precious.
Refine the mercury within the sand to become deathless,
Congeal the silver within the water to attain longevity.
When the nine cycles and nine returns are complete,
Surely the decrepit will be restored to youthful spring.

To plant the root of deathless longevity,
Nurture again the yin po and yang hun.
First instruct the Mystic Woman to return to the Li chamber,
Then dispatch the Empty King to guard the Kan gate.
When the tiger reaches the jia border, the wind howls,
When the dragon dwells within geng, the waters are warm.
Those lost on the path lightly divulge these secrets,
This principle must be entrusted to those who comprehend.

With eyes closed, visualize the spirit in the Jade Gate,
As the time arrives, the fire-timing is transmitted in turn.
Clouds soar over the sea as the dragon swallows mercury,
Wind strikes the cliff’s peak as the tiger subdues lead.
Once the treasure within the body is refined,
The mystery of the Dao is casually grasped.
After ingesting the knife’s measure, the scripture of the elixir descends,
Leaping beyond the dusty dragon to ascend the Nine Heavens.

A thousand days of effort, never idle,
The River Chariot bears its load up Mount Kun.
The tiger claps white mercury within the furnace,
The dragon emits red lead toward the crucible’s query.
The immortal registry records the name as the elixir ripens,
The netherworld’s ledger removes the entry as life is restored.
On what clouds do the feet alight as they return?
Straight into the Three Purities to thank the sacred countenance.

To match true yin with correct yang,
Three years of work complete, frost congeals.
The divine tortoise enters and exits the geng-xin position,
The cinnabar phoenix soars in the jia-yi direction.
The nine tripods first radiate twin auspicious qi,
Within the three primals, the five hairs’ light is renewed.
If in the dust there are those of like mechanism,
Together we shall dwell in the misty heavens of the deathless land.

The path of cultivating life is difficult within,
The deluded merely pore over ten thousand scrolls.
Water and fire balanced—this is the medicine,
Yin and yang askew—no elixir forms.
Abide in the feminine without losing the masculine to dwell,
In darkness, without deficiency, the white naturally dries.
Recognizing this true and wondrous secret,
Why fear wind and rain hastening decay?

Having swallowed but a single grain, one is at peace,
The twelve-storied tower and nine-bend stream are linked.
The geng tiger circulates, feeding on sharp snow,
The jia dragon writhes, spouting numinous springs.
Lü’s second corresponds to three thousand days,
Within the nine nines, ninety thousand years extend.
Only when there is affinity may it be transmitted,
Never lightly divulged to others.

Who knows of the divine water in the Jade Flower Pool,
Within which lies the foundation of life and destiny?
Its operation depends on dragon and tiger,
Its drawing and adding rely entirely on Kan and Li.
Morning and evening, the yellow gold powder is exhausted,
In an instant, the jade-like marrow is refined.
After a thousand days of abstinence and ingestion,
One casually ascends the cloud ladder.

The clouds of the Nine Heavens are still, the crane flies lightly,
Holding the bamboo slip, it flits away from the Great Purity.
The red dust beyond the body changes at will,
The white stone within the furnace forms in an instant.
The nine-plumed phoenix dances in the void,
Five-colored clouds arise beneath the feet.
Turning the head, one returns to the heavens above,
Wishing to bring sweet rain to parched mortals.

The infant descends the jade steps in leisurely fashion,
Holding the mystic pearl, it comes straight down.
At midnight, purple clouds drape its plain form,
Several times, crimson qi veils the peach’s bloom.
In its faint smile, the mechanism turns,
As it lightly moves, doors and windows open.
This is the true child of my family,
How could the foolish and ignorant casually guess?

As soon as the heavenly tally descends from the Jade Capital,
Three thousand days accumulate effort.
Praying to Heaven and Earth, the golden crucible opens,
Gathering yin and yang, the jade pot is sealed.
Suddenly, the mortal frame is capable of transformation,
Deeply knowing the wondrous Dao is no empty scheme.
When the time comes, ask the elders in the dust,
Does this mystery exist in the world?

Who recognizes the accomplished ones in the world,
Those who in their lives understand the method of silver in water?
A single staff props up Heaven and Earth,
A three-foot Kunwu sword slays gods and demons.
Deeply drunk, they sleep in the moonlit grotto,
Loftily chanting, they scorn the red dust.
Since awakening within, for the rest of their lives,
They have won the eternal spring of Penglai.

The red furnace advances the ridicule to refine golden essence,
A single numinous pearl pierces the chamber with light.
Shaking Heaven and Earth reveals the power of the Dao,
Escaping life and death demonstrates the work’s progress.
Carefree, they leave traces across the Four Seas,
Returning to the Three Purities to establish their names.
Straight up the five-cloud path, the journey is steady,
Purple simurghs and vermilion phoenixes come to welcome them.

If people of this age wish to learn longevity,
First, the pivot must move day and night.
Within the indistinct, focus the will and qi,
Within the void, solidify the original essence.
Dragon befriends tiger, three cycles complete,
Hare runs, crow flies, nine returns are achieved.

When Nine and Six unite, the Dao and qi harmonize,
The River Chariot day and night surges with golden waves.
With each exhalation, it turns at every pass,
With each inhalation, it rubs along the pulse points.
Lightning flashes at the Gate of Li, illuminating sea and mountain,

chunks.original_text: 炼出一炉神圣药，五云归去路分明。 亦无得失亦无言，动即施功静即眠。 驱遣赤牛耕宇宙，分张玉粒种山川。 栽培不惮劳千日，服食须知活万年。 今日示君君好信，教君见世作神仙。 不须两两与三三，柢在昆仑第一岩。 逢润自然情易伏，遇炎常恐性难降。 有时直入三元户，无事还归九曲江。 世上有人烧得住。 寿齐天地更无双。 本末无非在玉都，亦曾陆地作凡夫。 吞精食气先从有，悟理归真便入无。 水火自然成既济，阴阳和合自相符。 炉中炼出延年药，瞑渤从教变复枯。 无名无利任优游，遇酒逢歌且唱酬。 数载未曾经圣阙，千年唯只在仙州。 寻常水火三回进，真个夫妻一处收。 药就功成身羽化，更抛尘室出凡流。 杳杳冥冥莫问涯，雕虫篆刻道之华。 守中绝学方知奥，抱一无言始见佳。 自有物如黄菊蕊，更无色似碧桃花。 休将心地虚劳用，煮铁烧金转转差。 还丹功满未朝天，且向人问度有绿。 拄杖两头担日月，葫芦一个隐山川。 诗昤自得闲中句，酒饮多遗醉后钱。 若问我修何妙法，不离身内汞和铅。 半红半黑道中玄，水养真金火养铅。 解接往年三寸气，还将运动一周天。 烹煎尽在阴阳力，进退须凭日月权。 只此功成三岛外，稳乘鸾凤谒诸仙q 返本还元已到乾，能升能降号飞仙。 一阳生是兴功日，九转周为得道年。 炼药但寻金裹水，安炉先立地中天。 此处便是还丹理，不遇奇人誓莫传。 飞龙九五已升天，次第还当赤帝权。 喜遇汞珠凝正午，幸逢铅母结重玄。 狂猿自伏何须炼，野马亲调不着鞭。 炼就一丸天上药，顿然心地永刚坚。 举世何人悟我家，我家别是一荣华。 盈箱贮积登仙录，满室收藏伏火砂。 顿饮长生天上酒，常栽不死洞中花。 凡流若问吾生计，遍地纷纷五彩霞。 津能充渴气充粮，家住三清玉帝乡。 金鼎炼来多外白，玉虚烹处彻中黄。 始知青帝离宫住，方信金精水府藏。 流俗要求玄妙理，参同契有两三行。 紫诏随鸾下玉京，元君相命会三清。 便将金鼎丹砂饵。 时拂霞衣鹤驾行。 天上双童持佩引，月中娇女执婶迎。 此时功满参真后，始信仙都有姓名。 修修修得到乾乾，方号人问一醉仙。 世上光阴催短景，洞中花木任长年。 形飞峭壁非凡骨，神在玄宫别有天。 唯愿先生频一顾，更玄玄外问玄玄。 无心独坐转黄庭，不遂时流入利名。 救老只存真一气，修生长遗百神灵。 朝朝炼液归琼府，夜夜朝元养玉英。 莫叹老人贫里乐，十年功满上三清。 别客。 时人受气禀阴阳，均体乾坤寿命长。 为产本宗能寿永，因轻元祖遂沦亡。 三宫自有回流法，万物那无运用方。 咫尺昆仑山上玉，几人知是药中王。 别客。 青霄一路少人行，休话兴亡事不成。 金榜因何无姓字，玉都必是有仙名。 云归大海龙千尺，月满长空鹤一声。 深谢宋朝明圣主，解书丹诏诏先生。 赠陈处上。 天网恢恢万象疏，一身亲到华山区。 寒云去后留残月，春雪来时问太虚。 六洞真人归紫府，千年鸾鹤老苍梧。 自从遗却先生后，南北束西少丈夫。 哭陈先生。 罗浮道士谁同流，草衣木食轻王侯。 世问甲子管不得，壶裹乾坤只自由。 数着残棋江月晓，一声长啸海山秋。 饮余回首话归路，遥指白云天际头。 赠罗浮道士。 三千里外无家客，七百年来云水身。
chunks.translated_text:
Having refined a crucible of sacred elixir,
The path home through the five-colored clouds grows clear.
No gain nor loss, no words to speak—
In motion, they perform their work; in stillness, they rest.
They drive the crimson ox to plow the cosmos,
Scatter jade grains to sow the mountains and rivers.
Cultivating without fear of a thousand days’ labor,
They know that partaking grants ten thousand years of life.
Today I show you, for you are trustworthy—
I teach you to become an immortal in this world.
No need for pairs or trios,
Only at Kunlun’s first crag.
When moisture comes, the passions naturally submit;
When heat arrives, the nature fears it cannot be tamed.
At times they enter the Three Primordials’ gate,
When idle, they return to the Nine Bends’ river.
In this world, some can endure the firing—
Their lifespan matches Heaven and Earth, peerless in all.
From beginning to end, all lies within the Jade Capital,
Though once they walked the earth as ordinary men.
First, they swallowed essence and consumed qi from the realm of being,
Then, awakening to principle, they returned to truth and entered non-being.
Water and fire naturally achieve the *ji ji*,
Yin and yang harmonize and correspond of themselves.
From the furnace, the elixir of extended years is refined,
While the seas and tides may shift from flourishing to withering.
Free from fame and profit, they roam at ease,
Meeting wine and song, they join in the revelry.
For years, they have not passed through the sacred gates,
A thousand years they dwell only in the immortal realm.
Thrice they advance with water and fire,
Truly, husband and wife are gathered in one place.
Once the elixir is complete and the work accomplished, the body takes flight,
Leaving the dusty chamber to rise above the mortal stream.
Vast and boundless, ask not where it ends—
Carving insects and seal script are but the blossoms of the Dao.
Only by guarding the center and forsaking learning does one grasp the profound;
Embracing the One in silence, one first perceives the sublime.
There is a thing like the yellow chrysanthemum’s pistil,
Yet no color like the green peach blossom.
Do not wear out the mind’s earth with vain effort,
For smelting iron and refining gold only leads further astray.
When the returning elixir’s work is complete but they have not yet ascended to Heaven,
They first guide others among men to find their own verdant path.
A staff at both ends bears the sun and moon,
A single gourd conceals the mountains and rivers.
Poems flow freely in moments of leisure,
Wine is drunk in abundance, leaving coins behind in drunkenness.
If you ask what wondrous method I cultivate,
It is none other than the mercury and lead within the body.
Half red, half black—the mystery of the Dao,
Water nurtures true gold, fire nurtures lead.
They reconnect the three inches of qi from past years,
And circulate it through one cycle of Heaven.
The refining depends entirely on the power of yin and yang,
Advancing and retreating must rely on the authority of sun and moon.
Once this work is complete beyond the Three Isles,
They steadily ride simurghs and phoenixes to meet the immortals.
Returning to the origin and restoring the primordial has reached Qian,
Able to ascend and descend, they are called the Flying Immortals.
The arising of the first yang is the day to begin the work,
Nine revolutions complete the year of attaining the Dao.
To refine the elixir, seek the water within gold,
To establish the furnace, first set up Heaven within Earth.
Here lies the principle of the returning elixir—
Without encountering an extraordinary person, vow not to transmit it.
The nine-and-five flying dragon has ascended to Heaven,
In due course, the power of the Red Emperor will follow.
Delighted to meet the mercury pearl congealing at high noon,
Fortunate to encounter the lead mother forming the profound mystery.
The wild ape submits of itself—what need for refinement?
The untamed horse is tamed without the whip.
Once the single pill of Heaven’s elixir is refined,
The mind’s earth becomes forever firm and unyielding.
Who in this world understands my family?
My family dwells in a glory apart.
Their overflowing chests store the Registers of Ascension,
Their rooms are filled with cinnabar refined by fire.
They drink the immortal wine of Heaven in great draughts,
And constantly cultivate the undying flowers of the grotto.
If the mortal stream asks of my livelihood,
Everywhere, multicolored clouds scatter in profusion.
Saliva quenches thirst, qi serves as sustenance,
Their home lies in the Three Purities’ realm of the Jade Emperor.
When refined in the golden crucible, the outer turns white,
When cooked in the Jade Void, the inner becomes thoroughly yellow.
Only then do they know the Azure Emperor dwells in the Li Palace,
Only then do they trust that the golden essence is stored in the Water Mansion.
The common crowd seeks the wondrous principle,
Yet the *Cantong Qi* holds but a few lines.
A purple edict descends with the simurgh from the Jade Capital,
The Primordial Lord summons them to the Three Purities.
They then partake of the cinnabar from the golden crucible,
Brushing their cloud-embroidered robes as they ride the crane’s carriage.
Two celestial youths bear the jade pendants to guide them,
Fair maidens of the moon hold the sashes to welcome them.
Only after their work is complete and they have met the Perfected,
Do they truly believe the immortal capital holds their names.
Cultivating, cultivating, until they reach Qian,
They are then called the Drunken Immortals among men.
In the world, time hurries the brief scenes of life,
Yet in the grotto, flowers and trees enjoy endless years.
Their form soars on sheer cliffs, no ordinary bones,
Their spirit dwells in the Mysterious Palace, a Heaven apart.
I only wish the master would glance this way again,
To inquire beyond the profound into the even more profound.
Sitting alone with an empty mind, they turn the Yellow Court,
Not following the times into profit and fame.
To preserve age, they hold only the true unified qi,
To cultivate life, they leave behind the hundred spirits.
Morning by morning, they refine the fluid and return it to the Jade Mansion,
Night by night, they face the origin to nurture the Jade Flower.
Do not sigh that the old man finds joy in poverty,
For with ten years of work complete, they ascend to the Three Purities.

**Parting from the Guest**
Men receive qi and are endowed with yin and yang,
Their bodies equal Heaven and Earth, their lifespans long.
Those who honor their origins can live forever,
Those who slight their primal ancestors fall into oblivion.
The Three Palaces have their own method of reversing the flow,
All things possess their own means of operation.
The jade of Kunlun’s mountain, close at hand,
How many know it is the king of medicines?

**Parting from the Guest**
Few tread the path to the azure clouds,
Speak not of rise and fall—such matters never succeed.
Why is there no name on the golden tablet?
In the Jade Capital, there must be an immortal’s name.
Clouds return to the vast sea, dragons a thousand feet long,
The moon fills the long sky, a crane’s cry rings out.
Deep gratitude to the enlightened sage-emperor of the Song,
Who understood the vermilion edict and summoned the master.

**Presented to Chen Chushang**
The net of Heaven is vast, its mesh wide,
Yet one body comes alone to the Hua Mountains’ region.
After the cold clouds depart, the waning moon remains,
When spring snow arrives, it inquires of the Great Void.
The Six Grottoes’ Perfected return to the Purple Mansion,
A thousand years of simurghs and cranes grow old in Cangwu.
Since the master’s passing,
In all directions, few remain who are true men.

**Lament for Master Chen**
Who among the Daoists of Luofu shares his stream?
Clad in grass, eating bark, they scorn kings and lords.
In the world, the sexagenary cycle matters not to them,
Within their gourd, Heaven and Earth are free.
Counting the moves of a half-finished game as the river moon dawns,
A long whistle echoes through the autumn mountains and seas.
After drinking, they turn their heads to speak of the return,
Pointing afar to the white clouds at the edge of the sky.

**Presented to the Daoist of Luofu**
A wanderer three thousand *li* from home,
A cloud-and-water body for seven hundred years.

chunks.original_text: 行满蓬莱为别馆，道成瓦砾尽黄金。 待宾袖裹常存酒，化药炉中别有春。 积德求师何患少，由来天地不私亲。 兹僧见。 天生一物变三才，交感阴阳结圣胎。 龙虎顺行阴鬼去，龟蛇逆往火龙来。 婴儿日吃黄婆髓，姥女时飧白玉杯。 功满自然居物外，人间寒暑任轮回。 吕祖志卷之四竟 #1：『相』原缺，据《道藏辑要》本补 吕祖志卷五 艺文志 七言律诗六十一首 星辰聚会入离乡，日月盈亏助药王。 三候火烧金鼎宝，五符水炼玉壶浆。 乾坤反覆龙收雾，卯酉相吞虎放光。 入室用机擒捉取，一丸丹点体纯阳。 发头滴血眼如环，吐气云生怒世问。 争奈不平千万事，须期一诀荡凶顽。 蛟龙斩处翻沧海，暴虎除时拔远山。 为臧世情兼负义，剑光腥染点痕班。 雨雪霏霏天已暮，金锺满劝抚焦桐。 诗吟席上未移刻，剑舞筵前疾似风。 何事行杯当午夜，忽然怒目便腾空。 不知谁是亏忠孝，拥个人头入坐中。 赠剑客二首。 金丹一粒定长生，须得真铅炼甲庚。 火取南方赤凤髓，水求北海黑龟精。 鼎追四季中央合，药遣三元八卦行。 斋戒兴功成九转，定应入口鬼神惊。 碧潭深处一真人，貌似桃花体似银。 须发未斑绿有术，红颜不老为通神。 蓬莱要去如今去，架上黄衣化作云。 任彼桑田变沧海，一丸凡药定千春。 炉养丹砂鬓不斑，假将名利住人问。 已逢志士传神药，又喜同流动笑颜。 老子道经分付得，紫微星许共相攀。 幸蒙上士甘捞拢，处世输君一个闲。 赠人。 谁解长生是我栽，炼成真气在三台。 尽知白日升天去，刚逐红尘下世来。 黑虎行时倾雨露，赤龙耕处产琼瑰。 只吞一粒金丹药，飞入青霄更不回。 乱云堆裹表星都，认得探藏大丈夫。 绿酒醉眠闲日月，白苹风定钓江湖。 长将气度随天道，不把言词问世徒。 山水路遥人不到，茆君消息近知无。 鹤为车驾酒为粮，为恋长生不死乡。 地脉尚能缩得短，人年岂不展教长。 星辰往往壶中见，日月时时袖裹藏。 若欲时流亲得见，朝朝不离水银行。 灵芝无种亦无根，解饮能飧自返魂。 但得烟霞供岁月，任他乌兔走乾坤。 婴儿只恋阳中母，姥女须朝顶上尊。 一得不回千古内，更无冢墓示儿孙。 世上何人会此言，休将名利挂心田。 等闲倒尽十分酒，遇兴高吟一百篇。 物外姻霞为伴倡，壶中日月任婵娟。 他时功满归何处，直驾云车入洞天。 玄门弟子坐中央，得筹明良感玉皇。 枕下山河和雨露，笛中日月混潇湘。 坎男会遇退金女，离女交腾嫁木郎。 真个夫妻齐守志，立教牵惹在阴阳。 遥指高峰笑一声，红霞紫雾面前生。 每於尘市无人识，长到山中有鹤迎。 时弄玉蟾驱鬼魅，夜煎金鼎煮琼英。 他时若赴蓬莱洞，知我仙家有姓名。 堪笑时人问我家，杖担云物惹烟霞。 眉藏火电非他说，手种金莲不自夸。 三尺焦桐为活计，一壶美酒是生涯。 骑龙远出游三岛，夜久无人饭月华。 九曲江边坐卧看，一条长路入天端。 庆云捧拥朝丹阙，瑞气徘徊起白烟。 铅汞此时为至药，坎离今日结神丹。 功能济命长无老，只在人心不是难。 玄门玄理又玄玄，不死根元在汞铅。 知是一般真个卫，调和六一也同天。 玉京山上羊儿闹，金水河中石虎眠。 妙要能生觉本体，勤心到处自如然。 公卿虽贵不曾酬，说者仙卿便去游。
chunks.translated_text:
When merit is complete, Penglai becomes a guest pavilion;
When the Dao is perfected, tiles and rubble turn to gold.
In the sleeves for welcoming guests, wine is ever stored;
Within the alchemy furnace, another spring abides.

Virtue amassed and masters sought—what lack to fear?
Since ancient times, Heaven and Earth show no partiality.
This monk now appears.

Heaven births one thing, transforming into the Three Powers;
Yin and yang interact, congealing the sacred embryo.
Dragon and tiger proceed in order, banishing yin ghosts;
Tortoise and serpent reverse their course, and the fire dragon arrives.
The Infant daily consumes the Yellow Dame’s marrow;
The Crone feasts on the White Jade Cup.
When merit is complete, one naturally dwells beyond things;
In the human realm, cold and heat follow their cycles.

*Record of Ancestor Lü, Scroll Four ends*

**Record of Ancestor Lü, Scroll Five**
**Literary Records**
**Sixty-One Seven-Character Regulated Verses**

Stars and constellations gather, departing the *Li* homeland;
The waxing and waning of sun and moon aid the Medicine King.
For three periods, fire refines the golden tripod’s treasure;
With five talismans, water cooks the jade pot’s broth.
Heaven and Earth invert, the dragon gathers mist;
At *Mao* and *You*, the tiger devours and radiates light.
Entering the chamber, seize the mechanism—
A single cinnabar pellet transmutes the body into pure yang.

Blood drips from the hairline, eyes like rings;
Breath exhaled forms clouds, enraged at the world.
How to endure the myriad injustices?
A single formula must sweep away the fierce and stubborn.
Where the flood dragon is slain, the deep sea churns;
When the raging tiger is vanquished, distant mountains are uprooted.
For burying worldly passions and bearing righteousness,
The sword’s gleam is stained with bloody marks.

Snow falls thickly as dusk descends;
Golden goblets urge the strumming of the scorched paulownia.
Poems recited at the feast, moments unmeasured;
The sword dances before the banquet, swift as the wind.
Why raise cups at midnight?
Suddenly, eyes blaze with fury, and he soars into the void.
Who among them lacks loyalty or filial piety?
A head is seized and brought to the seat.

**Two Poems Presented to the Sword Guest**

A single golden pellet of elixir ensures longevity;
True lead must be refined with *jia* and *geng*.
Fire draws the red phoenix’s marrow from the south;
Water seeks the black turtle’s essence from the northern sea.
The tripod follows the four seasons, uniting at the center;
The medicine is dispatched through the three origins and eight trigrams.
With fasting and discipline, the nine transformations are achieved—
Surely, upon entering the mouth, even ghosts and spirits are startled.

Deep in the emerald pool, a true man resides,
His countenance like peach blossoms, his form like silver.
Though his hair and beard remain unblemished, he possesses the art;
His rosy complexion never ages, for he communes with the divine.
To Penglai he must go—now is the time to depart;
The yellow robe on the rack transforms into clouds.
Though mulberry fields may turn to vast seas,
A single pill of common medicine secures a thousand springs.

The furnace nurtures cinnabar, temples unmarred by gray;
Borrowing fame and profit, he dwells among men.
Having met a man of resolve who transmits the divine medicine,
He delights in kindred spirits, his smile ever bright.
The *Dao De Jing* of Laozi is entrusted to him;
The Purple Tenuity Star permits their shared ascent.
Fortunate to be gathered by a superior man,
In this world, he yields to none in leisure.

**Presented to a Person**

Who understands that long life is my planting?
Refining true *qi* within the Three Terraces.
Knowing full well the ascent to heaven in broad daylight,
Yet following the red dust back to the world.
When the black tiger moves, rain and dew pour forth;
Where the red dragon plows, jasper and coral grow.
Swallowing but one pellet of golden elixir,
He soars into the azure skies, never to return.

Amid piled clouds stands the starry capital;
Only the bold recognize the hidden treasure.
Green wine lulls him to sleep through idle days and months;
White duckweed stills the wind as he fishes rivers and lakes.
Ever aligning his bearing with the Dao of Heaven,
He does not waste words on worldly fools.
The mountain paths are distant, untrodden by men—
Has anyone lately heard news of Lord Mao?

Cranes serve as chariots, wine as provisions,
For he yearns for the land of immortality, where none die.
If earth’s veins can be shortened,
Why not extend human years?
Stars and constellations often appear within the gourd;
Sun and moon are ever concealed in his sleeves.
Should you wish for the common folk to meet him,
He never strays from the path of mercury.

Magic mushrooms have no seed nor root,
Yet those who drink and consume them revive their souls.
As long as mist and rosy clouds sustain the years,
Let the crow and hare race through Heaven and Earth.
The Infant clings only to the mother within yang;
The Crone must face the honored one atop her head.
Once attained, it remains for a thousand ages—
No tombs or graves are left for descendants.

Who in this world comprehends these words?
Cease clinging to fame and profit in your heart.
Casually downing cups of wine to the full,
When inspired, chanting a hundred verses.
Beyond the world, rosy clouds serve as companions;
Within the gourd, sun and moon are ever fair.
When the time comes and merit is complete, where will he return?
Straightaway driving a cloud chariot into the grotto-heavens.

Disciples of the Mysterious Gate sit at the center;
Obtaining the tally, the wise and good move the Jade Emperor.
Beneath the pillow, mountains and rivers harmonize with rain and dew;
Within the flute, sun and moon merge with Xiao and Xiang.
The *Kan* man meets the retiring *Jin* woman;
The *Li* woman ascends to wed the *Mu* youth.
Truly, husband and wife together uphold their resolve,
Establishing teachings that entangle yin and yang.

Pointing afar to the high peak, he laughs aloud—
Red rosy clouds and purple mists arise before him.
Often in the dusty market, none recognize him;
Ever in the mountains, cranes welcome him.
At times, he plays with the jade toad to drive away ghosts and demons;
At night, he boils the golden tripod to cook jasper blossoms.
When the time comes to journey to Penglai’s grotto,
Know that my immortal family bears a name.

**Mocking the Worldly**

How laughable are those who ask of my home—
A staff bearing clouds and things, trailing mist and rosy clouds.
His brows conceal lightning—no idle boast;
His hands plant golden lotuses—no vain pride.
A scorched paulownia, three feet long, sustains his livelihood;
A gourd of fine wine is his way of life.
Riding a dragon, he roams far to the three isles;
Through long nights, none share his moonlit repast.

By the winding river’s bend, he sits and lies in contemplation;
A single long path leads to the heavens’ edge.
Auspicious clouds gather to attend the cinnabar palace;
Auspicious vapors linger, rising as white smoke.
Lead and mercury now become the supreme medicine;
*Kan* and *Li* today conjoin the divine elixir.
Its power can preserve life, ensuring endless youth—
It lies within the human heart, not in difficulty.

The Mysterious Gate’s principles are ever more profound;
The root of immortality resides in mercury and lead.
Knowing this as the true guardian,
Harmonizing the Six and One also aligns with Heaven.
On Jade Capital Mountain, lambs frolic;
In the Golden Water River, stone tigers slumber.
The essential wonder can birth the awakened original body—
With diligent heart, all becomes naturally so.

Though high officials may be noble, he does not respond;
Those who speak of immortality are free to wander.

In the world, the sexagenary cycle matters not to them,
Within their gourd, Heaven and Earth are free.
Counting the moves of a half-finished game as the river moon dawns,
A long whistle echoes through the autumn mountains and seas.
After drinking, they turn their heads to speak of the return,
Pointing afar to the white clouds at the edge of the sky.

**Presented to the Daoist of Luofu**
A wanderer three thousand *li* from home,
